title: scotlands-rail-fares-set-price-hike----much
story: Those travelling on the railway could be faced with a .% increase in season tickets from as early as January ndash however it is understood ministers are considering delaying the  rise due to low passenger numbers as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.The Scottish Government, as well as their UK and Welsh counterparts, regulate rises for around half of fares, including season tickets on most commuter routes, some off-peaktickets on long-distance journeys, and tickets for travel around major cities at any time.Despite the rise, Transport Scotland bosses say ScotRail fares are on average % cheaper than those across the rest of the UK.Examples of potential season ticket prices next year after a .% rise include:A Transport Scotland spokeswoman said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to ensuring that rail fares are affordable for passengers and taxpayers across Scotland.ldquoWe have taken action to keep fares down and ScotRail fare are still on average, % cheaper than those across the rest of the UK.ldquoWe are currently in the process of considering the options regarding future fares and tickets in relation to todayrsquos announcement on the July RPI figure as part of the wider rail recovery work post the Covid- pandemic.UK Government Department for Transport figures show car use has nearly ed to pre-pandemic levels, but rail travel is below a third of what it was before the crisis despite lockdown restrictions easing.All revenue and cost risks from train companies were transferred to the UK, Scottish and Welsh governments in March to avoid franchises collapsing.This has already cost taxpayers at least pound. billion.

title: plan-electric-bikes-hire-towns-across-east-lothian
story: East Lothian Council has unveiled a wide range of temporary changes planned across its towns and surrounding communities to help social distancing.And in the longer term, council officers have outlined plans to capitalise on the increase in walking and cycling seen during lockdown by making it easier for people to continue leaving cars at home.Changes, some already in place, will transform town centres and while the work, which is being done under the Spaces for People project, is stressed as being temporary, council officers have said they hope it will be the first step to making East Lothian low carbon as part of its ClimatEvolution.From reducing speed limits in towns and some communities to mph to introducing pop-up cycle paths and lanes and extending pavements, the councilrsquos Spaces for People plans are already changing town centres.One of the most eye-catching developments is the plan to have e-bikes for hire in many county towns.ldquoTo provide alternatives to taking the bus in these uncertain times, e-bike hire stations are being progressed for each of our towns, the council has stated.ldquoElectric or e-bikes will provide an alternative choice for public transport users, and non-vehicle owners. E-bikes offer a greater mileage for commuting with less physical effort required and a safer means of physical distancing.ldquoE-bike public hire stations, which will be managed by another company, will be installed in Musselburgh at the Brunton Hall and next to Musselburgh Train Station in autumn.ldquoE-bike hire areas in other towns across East Lothian are proposed. In addition, discussions are ongoing with local bike shop businesses as to how they can support the public hire scheme.Public Bike Shareschemes have been introduced across the world, with many using docks which lock the bicycles in and release them for a small fee or with use of a card to users however, their success in the UK has been limited, with vandalism a major concern.In London, Santander Cycles operates a successful scheme which has spread to Swansea and Milton Keynes, with users issued a key to access the bicycles, which cost pound and allow free use for the first  minutes and then charge pound for every additional  minutes.East Lothian Council said that as well as Musselburgh, there were plans to have public hire stations for e-bikes in Haddington town centre and at Prestonpans Railway Station, Longniddry Railway Station, Memorial Square in Prestonpans, Civic Square in Tranent and Memorial Park in Cockenzie, each of which would have capacity for eight bikes.East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill described the changes as ldquoreclaiming the streets.He said: ldquoThis is a challenge but equally an opportunity, offering other public health improvements, as well as the required social distancing. Reducing air pollution and promoting walking and cycling will have benefits for us all. Providing adequate car parking remains essential, with vehicular access understandably restricted. Itrsquos not easy but it can be done. As communities on the continent have discovered, people reclaiming their streets has benefits for all.Iain Gray, East Lothian MSP, said: ldquoThe substantial increase in the number of people walking and cycling, both locally and across the UK, was one of the positive unintended consequences of lockdown.ldquoThis clearly brings benefits for both the health of the iniduals doing more walking and cycling, and for the environmentit means fewer vehicles on our roads.ldquoTherefore, I welcome measures to encourage and support the continuation of this growth in walking and cycling as we move out of lockdown.ldquoHowever, changes must be designed and implemented with ongoing consultation with the local communities affected.In a report to councillors, Peter Forsyth, the councilrsquos assets manager, revealed ambitions to make the most of the side effects of lockdown.He said: ldquoThe Covid- shutdown has resulted in less air pollution and reduced greenhouse gas emissions primarily due to extensive travel restrictions. Other positive impacts have included reduced energy consumption, and increased walking and cycling. Accordingly, there are opportunities for a lsquoGreen Recoveryrsquo, adapting to new ways of working with increased changes to travel behaviour all in support to the transition to a low carbon economy and low carbon lestyles for the longer term that will enable us to continue to tackle the climate emergency.A council spokesperson said: ldquoAs part of Spaces for People, we are proposing the installation of e-bikes in suitable locations. E-bikes are becoming increasingly popular as an active travel option which could be potentially attractive as an alternative form of clean, green transportation. We are still at the early stages and look forward to pursuing this further and will provide further information in due course.

title: petition-museum-flight-plans-signed-nearly-6-500
story: The new visitor centre for the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune was refused planning permission by East Lothian Council after it involved cutting down the trees in an ancient woodland to allow planes to be moved into it.National Museums Scotland has lodged an appeal over the rejection of its plans with Scottish Ministers.It said the tree removal was required to ldquodecant large fixed-wing aircraft from their current home to the new indoor exhibition centre, and saplings would be planted to replace the lost woodland.However, objectors argued that an alternative site could still be found and the need to protect the woodland far outweighed the need for the new centre.More than  written objections have been lodged with the Scottish Government Reporter as part of the appeal however, an online petition was rejected initially because it was said to be the wrong format.That decision has now been overruled by the Reporter, who has allowed the petition, which has , names on it, to be included in evidence.Alerting National Museums Scotland and East Lothian Council to the decision, case officer Laura Walker said: ldquoAn external link webpage was sent to myself back in June. The link openedup to a petition. I rejected this due to the format it was submitted .ldquoThe Reporter has now agreed that the petition can be acceptedsent in by a dferent format, which the organiser has done. The Reporter has confirmed an unaccompanied site visit will be carried out at the site proposed for the centre before a decision will be made over whether any additional information is required or a public hearing held.

title: east-lothian-council-peoples-energy-form-money-saving-partnership
story: East Lothian Energy will see the local authority work alongside Peoplersquos Energy to offer affordable, sustainable and fair energy for residents throughout the county as part of a joint commitment to eradicate fuel poverty.The new initiative sees Peoplersquos Energy, in association with the council, offering a special iable and fixed tarf that is discounted from its regular tarfs and available exclusively to East Lothian residents.The offer equates to potential savings of up to pound annually compared with the current energy price cap , based on Ofgemrsquos medium typical domestic consumption values energy usage.Councillor Norman Hampshire, council spokesman for the environment, described the scheme as ldquoquite a unique initiative.He said: ldquoEast Lothian Energy gives county residents the exclusive opportunity to purchase affordable, sustainable and fair energy. We hope this will be attractive to householders across a mix of tenures ndash including tenants and homeowners.ldquoAs well as saving money and helping to reduce fuel poverty, East Lothian Energy is a great way of enabling customers to support the environment and tackling climate change ndash a key priority for us as a council.ldquoThat is because all of the electricity comes from  per cent renewable sources.ldquoEast Lothian Energy customers will receive automatic Peoplersquos Energy membership ndash with  per cent of their profits being paid back to domestic members through an annual rebate.David Pike, CEO and co-founder of Peoplersquos Energy, based at Danderhall, said: ldquoWithin East Lothian, it is estimated that almost a quarter of householdsare living in fuel poverty, equating to , homes.ldquoWith this new affordable tarf for East Lothian residents, we have the potential to reduce the fuel poverty gap in the area quite considerably.ldquoPeoplersquos Energy is a social enterprise that puts people and the planet before profits.ldquoWersquore delighted to have the opportunity to partner with East Lothian Council to help make a positive change.To sign up, visit peoplesenergy eastlothian

title: coronavirus-scotland-face-coverings-become-law-schools-workplaces
story: Nicola Sturgeon told her coronavirus briefing yesterday that it was ldquounder review, as the Scottish Government attempt to strike the right balance between ldquobeing as normal as possible and the learning experience for young people.It comes after a number of confirmed COVID- cases were reported in pupils across the country ndash with classes and even whole schools having to self-isolate.Face coverings could become mandatory in secondary schoolsA public health expert has since said that the mandatory wearing of masks in workplaces and secondary schools should be considered to keep them open.Coverings are compulsory in many indoor settings including shops, on public transport and in places such as cinemas, galleries, museums, libraries and banks.Professor Linda Bauld said they could be considered in other settingslevels of coronavirus go up.What did she say Asked in an interview on BBC Radio Scotland whether introducing face coverings in workplaces should be considered to allow more people to get back to work, she said: ldquoI donrsquot think we should rule it out."I thinkcases go up and we need particular settings to reopen that canrsquot, for whatever reason, face coverings indoors absolutely, but at the moment those sectors that can work from home ndash thatrsquos the message that I agree with ndash should continue to do that.Prof Bauld, who is professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh, said the virus is at a ldquovery low level in terms of where we are in Scotland and that while it is circulating it is localised in terms of the rise in cases.Face coverings are already mandatory in some situationsShe said the best way to protect schools is to keep virus levels low, but that face coverings could be considered for secondary school pupils to avoid having to pause education.Prof Bauld said: ldquoIn terms of the cases that wersquore hearing about in school pupils, these are not cases that are occurring because pupils are catching the virus in the school setting, they are cases that are arising in the community, and when we have the virus circulating in the community even at low levels we know that children and young people may get it and then thereforethey go into the school they are still carrying it.She added: ldquoI thinkwe wanted to talk about, for example, face coverings for secondary school pupils rather than closing a school, thatrsquos another step we might want to discuss, thatrsquos being discussed in other places, but we donrsquot need it at the moment."We just have to think about what are the alternatives to having to pause education again because wersquore all trying to avoid that.Itrsquos now mandatory to wear a face covering in more indoor public places in Scotland.This video explains where you must wear one #Detailed guidance # https:t.co QmCaYPog pic YWJXeeHWhat did the First Minister say During her daily briefing yesterday, the First Minister addressed the concerns over cases in pupils ndash as well as responding to images of crowded hallways and playgrounds.Ms Sturgeon said the introduction of face masks in schools would not be ruled out.She said: "When we see anything like that, directors of education in relevant councils will be contacted to make sure they are applying all of the right guidance."We will keep all of this under review, and that includes face coverings, so that we are striking the right balance between as normal as possible in what is still an abnormal situation and learning experience for young people, but with the right mitigations in place."

title: muirfield-host-womens-open-first-time-2022
story: The world-famous course, which has held the menrsquos event  times, has been confirmed as the venue for the prestigious competition in .A decision to allow female members at Muirfield for the first time by the Honourable Company of Edinburgh Golfers was taken in . Previously, women had only been allowed to play the course as guests or visitors.A vote the previous year had seen a vote to scrap the clubs men-only policy fall narrowly short of the required two-thirds majority.Following that vote, the venue was removed from organisers The RAs rota for hosting The Open ndash it was reinstated following the  reversal of the men-only policy.Martin Slumbers, chief executive of The RA, was delighted with Muirfield receiving the  Womens Open, a decision which was announced on the eve of this yearrsquos event, which is being played at Royal Troon.Next year, Carnoustie will host the competition, which was won last year by Hinako Shibuno, with Muirfield then welcoming players in .Walton Heath , St Andrewsand Royal Porthcawlwere also announced as future venues.Mr Slumbers said: ldquoWith our partners at AIG, we have a real ambition to grow and elevate the AIG Womens Open for the benefit of the worlds leading golfers and so we are excited to confirm our intention to play the next five championships at these renowned courses.ldquoIt has truly been a collaborative effort from all the venues involved to make this schedule possible and the flexibility that they have shown in adjusting their own calendars has been vital in allowing us to confirm our plans for the championship through to .ldquoWe are grateful for their support, particularly during a time when golf has been impacted by the ongoing pandemic, and we look forward to working with these venues to deliver an outstanding experience to be enjoyed by everyone involved in the AIG Womenrsquos Open.North Berwicks Catriona Matthew won the tournament in , when it was hosted at Royal Lytham and St Annes.Muirfield, Walton Heath and Royal Porthcawl will all be hosting the womenrsquos major championship for the first time.Muirfield, near Gullane, has a prestigious history of hosting Major championships, having last held The Open in .Phil Mickelson lted the Claret Jug on that occasion and the course also hosted The Curtis Cup in  and , as well as the Vagliano Trophy in  and .Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who lives in nearby Gullane, described it as ldquogreat news for the club and great news for East Lothian.He said: ldquoThis part of East Lothian is not known as Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast for nothing.ldquoIt is the greatest stretch of golf courses in the whole of Scotland,not the whole of the UK, and Muirfield is the jewel in the crown that continues to attract visitors from all over the world, who want to play Muirfield, Gullane, North Berwick and Dunbar.ldquoWe saw the Ladies Scottish Open event [at The Renaissance Club, near Dirleton, last week] being held without spectators.ldquoIt is great to have it here but not having spectators is a great shame because that adds to the whole atmosphere and the draw.ldquoHopefully, in two yearsrsquo time, we have a vaccine [for Covid-] and we are back to as close to normal as possible.

title: storm-ellen-high-winds-expected-east-lothian
story: Although the storm is expected to be worst in the west, East Lothian and other parts of south-east Scotland are also due to be impacted.The Met Office has issued a yellow be aware warning of wind for East Lothian covering the period from am to pm tomorrow.The Met Office says that strong winds on Friday are expected to lead to some travel disruption and could possibly disrupt power as well.It says that some travel delays are likely, while some short term loss of power and other services is also possible."Itrsquos likely that some coastal routes, sea fronts and coastal communities are affected by spray and or large waves," the Met Office adds, as well as "some damage to trees, with debris on roads possible given the time of year".Although the storm is not predicted to be as severe as some of those in the early part of the year, the unseasonal nature of a storm of this type striking in summer is expected to bring its own problems, as trees are in full leaf and therefore could suffer more damage than usual.

title: coronavirus-phase-3-seven-new-things-can---gyms-update-revealed
story: Giving her three-weekly update to the Scottish Parliament, the First Minister set out some key changes to the route map out of lockdown.However, Ms Sturgeon confirmed that the country would not yet be moving into Phase .It comes as Scotland is currently dealing with a number of coronavirus clusters, and with schools having reopened to pupils last week.Driving lessons can resume from MondayLast month, the First Minister outlined a series of indicative dates for further changes to the lockdown rules, which she confirmed today.As of Monday, the following things will be permitted:The First Minister also provided an update on gyms and other events.Gyms and swimming pools can now reopen from August .Indoor sports courts can also open from that date.

title: phone-box-removal-35-list-40-east-lothian-taken-away
story: East Lothian Council gave the green light for the removal of  phone boxes across the county, with just two kept in use and three adopted for alternative use after a public consultation.Last week, vans were sent out to take away the last nine of the boxes marked for removal.BT said it had consulted with the local authority and communities over retaining the phone boxes before taking any action.A spokesperson said: ldquoMost people now have a mobile phone and calls made from our public telephones have fallen by around  per cent in the past decade.ldquoWe consider a number of factors before consulting on the removal of payphones, including whether others are available nearby and usage.ldquoWe consulted with East Lothian Council on the removal of  payphones and provided communities with the chance to comment on our proposals.ldquoIf the council tell us they want a payphone to remain, we will keep it.ldquoAs part of the consultation, we also offered communities the chance to adopt traditional red heritage phone boxes for just pound through our Adopt a Kiosk scheme.ldquoThe need for payphones in emergencies is also reducing as  per cent of the UK has either G or G coverage. As long as therersquos network coverage from at least one network, itrsquos possible to call , even when therersquos no credit or no coverage from your own mobile provider.Out of  phone boxes earmarked for removal, the local authority indicated only two were to remain active: Eskside West, Musselburgh and Bayswell Road, Dunbar.Three were adopted by community groups in West Saltoun, Dirleton and Bolton.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoAny decision on whether to remove a phone boxis for BT to make.ldquoAs part of its process, BT noties the local community and the council of any proposal intention to remove a phone box.ldquoThe councilrsquos role is to feed back any comments to BT from the local community.ldquoPhone boxes can be lsquoadoptedrsquo by local community or charity organisations.The consultation for the latest removals was launched last year.BT said only nine working phone boxesin East Lothian had not been put forward for public consultation over their future.In , there were an estimated  working phone kiosks in the county.Some phone boxes in the county have become iconic.In East Linton, the phone box on Drylaw Street was removed however, the one on the villagersquos High Street, which has category-B listed building status, was not on the list.It is a well-known tourist attraction which dates back to  and is often photographed by visitors.Judith Priest, from Dunpender Community Council, said attempts had been made to adopt the High Street box, without success.She said: ldquoItrsquos a sorry sight and we would like to adopt it.ldquoItrsquos a popular box and visitors from abroad take their photos with it but it hasnrsquot been painted in years.

title: gateside-retail-park-work-starts-site-haddington
story: Diggers and heavy machinery arrived at Gateside, on Haddingtonrsquos western edge, last week.Plans for a retail park, made up of five units, were given the green light by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee shortly before Christmas last year.However, work on the site has been slow due to the coronavirus pandemic and related restrictions.When complete, the development, which was submitted by EPICLtd, will include three major retail stores, two restaurants ndash with one including a drive-thru ndash and nearly  parking spaces.Aldi, Home Bargains and The Food Warehouse are all expected to move into the site as the retail stores, alongside Greggs and Costa as the restaurants.A new petrol station is also planned for the site, which is sandwiched between the A and B.When the proposals were revealed, it was suggested that  jobs would be created at the retail park, with a further  construction jobs during the building process.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-august-18-20-1995-1970-1920
story: lsquoENOUGH is enoughrsquo was the message from traders in North Berwick, reported the East Lothian Courier on August , .The opening of North Berwickrsquos sixth charity shop this week has sparked controversy ndash and fears have been raised that a seventh could be on the cards.Traders claimed the resort had now reached ldquosaturation point with fundraising outlets, which are now selling new goods in addition to second-hand items.They said the charities were setting up shop on prime sites, and argued that they were ldquosubsidising them through having to pay higher rates.Fears that the trend could ultimately lead to a downturn in the local economy and the death of the High Street as a shopping centre were also expressed.The row follows the opening of the Chest, Heart  Stroke Associationrsquos outlet at a former delicatessen shop in the High Street on Monday.A RE-ENACTMENT of the Battle of Dunbar was postponed as it clashed with a model power boat demonstration, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier of August , .The re-enactment of the Battle of Dunbar, which is to be staged by the Royal Scots as part of their recruiting drive in East Lothian, has been postponed for a week because it would have clashed with the running of a model power boat demonstration to be held on Sunday, September . It will now take place on September .The Royal Scots will be spending a weekend in Dunbar and will be holding a dance in the Victoria Ballroom for the youngsters.MEANWHILE, there was avisit from Australia.A Haddington man who joined the Australian Army almost  years ago is at present revisiting the town on a short holiday. He is Sgt. Alex. Sutherland, son of Mrs J. Sutherland and the late Mr Sutherland, of  Orchard Grove. Alex, who was a painter in Haddington, went to Sydney for training after signing up in London.lsquoATTEMPTED rescue of a prisonerrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier of August , .A young man named Alexander Broadfoot, residing at the Coalfauld, West Harbour, Cockenzie, appeared before Bailie Robertson at Edinburgh City Police Court on Monday, charged with committing a breach of the peace on Saturday, and assaulting two constables of the Edinburgh City Police. The accused pleaded guilty, and was fined pound with the option of  daysrsquo imprisonment.A second man, named Alexander Hope,  Queen Street, Edinburgh, admitted having attempted to rescue Broadfoot from the police.

title: zans-wildlife-diary-otter-esk
story: Although I love ying the subjects of my photographs and learning about new species as I travel across Scotland, my favourite animal remains the kingfisher at the River Esk at Musselburgh.Very often, when I go on a walk along the river, I chat with other wildle enthusiasts. This is how I heard about an otter at the Esk for the first time three years ago.A few people mentioned they had seen this elusive creature a few years ago, but never since.The otter became my new photography challenge. I tried visiting the river at dferent times of the day, especially at dawn and dusk, when otters are more active, always trying to keep the noise down to a minimum.After two years of searching, my hope was gone and I almost gave up. Until one sunny day in April during lockdownhellipThe weather that day was enjoyable, so Chris and I decided to go on a walk. The local path was very busy the dog walkers, cyclists, families with children and joggers were enjoying the sun whilst social distancing.As always, I kept my eyes low on the water hoping to see the kingfisher.As we followed the river upstream to the area at The Grove, I spotted something moving in the water.I grabbed Chrisrsquo hand and I pulled him down on the ground right behind a bush.It was not a kingfisher but something I did not expect to see in the middle of the day... an otter fishing!We managed to crawl down the slope and lie down so we would not disturbit.Whilst I was photographing the otter, I also heard a cheery pee-pee-pee and saw the kingfisher flying past the otter. What a day!Since then I have seen the otter a couple more times.The Eurasian otter is a secretive, semi-aquatic species with chocolate brown fur, webbed feet, and a powerful tail. Their thick coats are built of two layers of fur: an inner layer that works as insulation, and the outer, waterproof layer. The two-layered system prevents their skin from direct contact with water and subsequent temperature loss.Their nostrils and ears stay closed as otters swim underwater.Despite being excellent swimmers, they cannot hold their breath underwater for long periods the average time underwater is about  seconds as they e.Otters are solitary, territorial animals, that live in underground holes called lsquoholtsrsquo. The size of their territory ies and depends on the quality of the habitat, amount of food and number of possible holts.It is also known that a male otter has a larger territory that can even overlap several female ottersrsquo territories. Otters usually have a well-defined area within their grounds in which they feed, rest and breed.Seeing signs of otters is generally easier than seeing the animals themselves. If you happen to find yourself at the riverbank or a sea loch, look for five-toed footprints and otter droppings , that are left in places such as fallen trees, rocks and weirs.Spraints are easily identiable as they contain visible fish bones and have a characteristic and not particularly unpleasant smell that has been described as ranging from fish to freshly brewed jasmine tea!The otter that you may see at the coast is very often called a lsquosea otterrsquo however, this is the same species as the animals that live further inland.If you would like to share how you get on finding the otters oryou have any rare kind of wildle in your area, I would love to hear from you.Speak to you next month!zanslensfacebook zanslens instagram zans_lens twitter zans_lens

title: tantallon-castle-john-muir-birthplace-among-attractions-reopening
story: Historic Environment Scotlandhas confirmed that Tantallon Castle, east of North Berwick, will accept visitors with pre-booked tickets from next Friday .A phased reopening of some HES sites across the county has begun, but there is no date yet for when Dirleton Castle could reopen.Both of these county attractions closed in March when lockdown was initiated to combat the coronavirus pandemic.A statement from HES said: ldquoAfter what has felt like historyrsquos longest wait, the easing of certain lockdown restrictions means you and your family can now grab a well-earned change of scenery at a selection of our safe and secure sites.ldquoItrsquos a pleasure to welcome you back and we would like to thank you for your patience and perseverance in staying home during this pandemic.ldquoWhen you arrive at any of our reopening sites, wersquoll need to work together to make sure we are all following the rules and staying protected.Entry tickets for Tantallon Castle can now be pre-booked via the website historicenviron ment.scotWalk-up visitors without an advanced booking will not be able to gain entry.Meanwhile, in another boost for the countyrsquos residents and visitors, the museum telling the story of Dunbarrsquos most famous son has reopened its doors.The John Muir Birthplace Museum welcomed back visitors on Tuesday for the first time since the coronavirus outbreak started.The museum, on the townrsquos High Street, allows visitors to explore the le and legacy of the man recognised as the father of the US national park system, in the house where he was born.Meanwhile, further attractions are also available for visitors to see at the National Museum of Flight, East Fortune.Hangar had already been open, along with the historic airfield and the parachute store.Now, the military aviation and civil aviation hangars have also opened to the public.Lucy Casot, CEO of Museums Galleries Scotland, said: ldquoWith so many of our museums and galleries across Scotland now able to open, therersquos so much to choose from, many with wonderful outdoor spaces to enjoy with the whole family.ldquoItrsquos not just a fun day out museums and galleries have a positive impact on our social wellbeing as well as the local economy, so we are urging everyone to make a point of visiting their favourite museum or gallery.ldquoAdditionally, with many of us staycationing this year, it is a wonderful opportunity to discover more of Scotlandrsquos inspiring museums and galleries.

title: retired-musselburgh-nurse-writes-book-caring-people-dementia
story: Dee Jenkins, , of Eskmills Road, said the main aim of the publication ndash I Remember Dementia ndash was to encourage carers of dementia patients.Born in Dublin in , Mrs Jenkins, who has lived in Musselburgh for  years, came to Scotland in  to enter a religious order, the Novitiate for the Sisters of La Sagesse, at Leuchie House, North Berwick. When it closed as a convent, the home became available for respite work for multiple sclerosis sufferers.Mrs Jenkins went on to train at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh from  to . She then joined the initial team of nurses at St Columbarsquos Hospice when it opened in .Mrs Jenkins left the order after  years and moved to Wales in  to take up a position as matron in a care home specialising in dementia care.She continued to care for people with dementia after ing to Scotland in , spending a decade in Edinburgh until she retired at the age of .Mrs Jenkins said: ldquoI worked in independent care homes as a manager, with the responsibility of training staff in this specialised field.ldquoI was inspired to write the book because people are becoming more aware of dementia and conscious of the dficulties it involves.ldquoI hope that my experiences might encourage those caring at home and provide some practical help and guidance.She added: ldquoIrsquom aware that Musselburgh as a town has shown a consciousness and willingness to provide supportive groups in this field of care, and hope this book may be of additional help and interest.The book is available on Amazon.

title: emergency-recess-procedures-east-lothian-council-ending
story: For the past five months, all decision-making powers were delegated to Monica Patterson, chief executive of the local authority, and the leaders of each of the three political parties ndash Councillor Willie Innes or Norman Hampshire , previously Jane Henderson and now Lachlan Bruce , and Stuart Curriendash during Covid- emergency recess procedures.The decision to invoke those procedures was made at the council meeting on St Patrickrsquos Day, March , ahead of lockdown being brought in.That will now end, with a view to ing to full council meetings.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoIt is anticipated that the first meeting of the council on August  and, subject to consideration of a related report at that meeting, all other public meetings until further notice, will operate on a virtual basis accessible to the public.

title: new-knox-academy-s1-pupils-welcomed-special-cake
story: Reigning Scottish School Cook of the Year ndash and Knox Academyrsquos very own cook ndash Maria Millar conjured up some brilliant baking ahead of youngsters finishing their summer holidays.The cake, a school shirt complete with school tie and Knox Academyrsquos crest, came with the message: lsquoWelcome st year .rsquoMaria baked the cake for pupils heading to school last Thursday, with S pupils, including her son Andrew, invited to come and try a piece.She wanted to create a tasty masterpiece, as P pupils never got the chance to have the traditional leaving event when moving from primary school to secondary school due to the coronavirus pandemic.She added: ldquoI wanted to give something to welcome the S pupils.The vanilla sponge, with strawberry jam, went down well with the pupils and staff.Maria said: ldquoPeople were saying they could not believe I made it but I wanted to do something for Knox.The hundreds of pupils heading to the Haddington secondary school can expect gastronomic delights.Maria, who is originally from Venezuela, picked up the national honour last year for the second time.Her menu of turkey meatballs in a red sauce served with rice primavera, followed by tres leche ndash three milk ndash cake, which includes condensed milk, evaporated milk and double cream, impressed judges and saw her regain the title she won in .Sue Cook, headteacher at the school, thanked Maria.She said: ldquoIt was so lovely of Maria to make this welcome cake.ldquoAll our Ss were offered a piece at lunchtime, with most taking it home for later .ldquoNot only was the design bespoke, featuring our Knox Academy school unorm, but it was mouth-wateringly good, too.

title: firth-forth-lobster-hatchery-features-bbc-show-great-food-guys
story: Chef Nick Nairn, who runs four restaurants, two cookery schools and has one Michelin star, and presenter Dougie Vipond, of Landward and Sportscene, visited the Firth of Forth Lobster Hatchery, based at North Berwick Harbour, as part of the second series of their TV show The Great Food Guys.The lobster hatchery rears juvenile lobsters from the larvae hatched from local female lobster stock. It then nurtures the juveniles through their most vulnerable stages until they can be released into the sea.Although it was forced to delay its summer opening due to lockdown, the hatcheryrsquos education container was reopened in July.The hatcheryrsquos production container, however, has remained closed to the public as Covid- meant it was unable to perform its usual duties.As well as reporting from the lobster hatchery, Dougie and Nick visited the town in the Landward van for the show, tempting local residents with some of their dishes.This marks the second time East Lothian has appeared in the show, with Phantassie Food near East Linton and some North Berwick residents featuring in the showrsquos first episode in July.This latest episode, the seventh in an eight-part series, is shown this evening at pm on the BBC Scotland channel and on Saturday at .am on BBC One.The series was filmed last year, before lockdown.

title: north-berwick-high-school-pupils-left-bus-stop-gullane
story: North Berwick High Schoolrsquos parent council chairman took to social media to highlight concerns about incidents which had occurred,as youngsters from outwith the seaside town tried to use public services to get to class.Niall Bradley said he had been made aware of problems, ranging from bus timetables not matching new starting and going home times introduced, to buses not turning up, overcrowding and children being ldquoleft behind.His comments came after some parents vented their anger after pupils in Gullane were left at a bus stop on Monday morning, and were then told their normal service route had changed.East Coast Buses said it had been working with East Lothian Council to ensure there was enough provision for pupils and would continue to do so.And it said the issues had been caused by a ersion which was in place preventing its  service going to Gullane which has now been resolved.Mr Bradley took to social media to address the issue, saying: ldquoIrsquom aware of a list of concerns about buses: timings, buses not shaking up, overcrowding, children being left behind, failure to wearface coverings.ldquoI know some parents have written to the school, which is great, but Irsquove written to our ward councillors to make sure that they are aware of the issues and to ask them to take this up with Transport Services at East Lothian Council.One mum claimed pupils were again left stranded this morning in Gullane and others accused buses of failing to stop for pupils on the route, a claim denied by East Coast Buses.Another parent claimed some bus drivers were refusing to allow pupils to stand on the buses, while others were happy for them to crowd in, with claims some buses had children ldquostanding, sitting in the luggage racks and sitting on the stairs.The bus company said it had worked with the council to ensure capacity after months of a reduced service due to Covid-.A spokesperson said: ldquoIn advance of the schools reopening, we worked closely with East Lothian Council to add extra capacity to our network for children travelling to and from school.ldquoOn Monday, the first full day back for all school pupils, we encountered some minor issues predominately caused by a road closure and subsequent route ersions.ldquoAs a result not all pupils could be uplted as planned however, we have made a number of changes to increase overall capacity, including a timing change from Monday on the Service X to provide additional seats between Gullane and North Berwick at the time when children are travelling to school.ldquoAs we move forward, we will continue to liaise with East Lothian Council and local schools to continually review and introduce further changesand where required.North Berwick High School took to Twitter yesterday eveningto insist there was enough space on the bus servicestudents used the ldquoright ones.The school published its bus timetable with the comment: ldquoTransport have worked hard to resolve the issue with buses along the coastal routes.ldquoWe have plenty of capacity, provided pupils take the right buses to and from school, according to the timetable.An East Lothian Council spokesperson: ldquoThe  was not operating through Gullane due to roadworks in neighbouring West Fenton."Pupils in that area had separate transport arranged and our Transport Services team also arranged an additional  seater bus to service Gullane to compensate for the loss of service through Gullane. This was used by one pupil on its two days in operation.ldquoAs East Coast Buses is a public transport service, pupils are allowed to stand during transport. We also agree that face coverings should be worn as a mandatory requirement and are working with our schools and school communities to raise awareness of this national guidance."We are also working closely with North Berwick High School to align bus service timings with the schoolrsquos move to a common school day.ldquoHaving reviewed pupil numbers and available capacity on our buses we believe that there is sufficient capacity and the issues that are highlighting, notwithstanding the , are being exacerbated as most pupils have tried to access the very first bus to arrive."This was also highlighted when our own officer visited the village on Tuesday to better understand the issue. Again, we are working with our schools and transport providers to manage this process and would appreciate parental support. We would encourage pupils to make use of all buses serving the route.

title: enjoyleisures-six-sports-centres-east-lothian-reopen-september
story: enjoyleisure, which,operates six sports centres in East Lothian on behalf of East Lothian Council,announced this evening that its centres would reopen on Monday, September .Meanwhile, FES Ltd, which operates the Mercait Gait Centre in Prestonpans, has also announced the centres intention to reopen on September , "subject to change in the event of new Government advice".In a statement, enjoyleisure said: "Whilst we welcome todayrsquos statement from the First Minister, enjoyleisure is committed to reopening its sport, leisure centres and swimming pools in East Lothian from Monday, September , which was the indicative date provided by Scottish Government three weeks ago."The safety of our customers and colleagues is our number one priority. We will not make any compromises on this."Our sports centres are multaceted buildings. As such, the magnitude and complexity that is required to prepare our sports centres for reopening in line with the Scottish Government and each official sporting bodyrsquos guidance cannot be underestimated."We have however, already made signicant progress in preparing our centres for reopening by making changes to the way we deliver our services to protect the communities of East Lothian."A number of social distancing and hygiene measures will be introduced at all centres, which include increased spacing between gym equipment, distinguishing entry and exiting points, and hand sanitiser stations. Signicantly increased cleaning regimes by staff will be implemented throughout the day to safeguard our customers and employees."The layouts of the gyms have been changed to enable customers to use the equipment at a safe distance from others. There will be a limit to the number of people allowed in the gym at any one time, along with a fixed -minute session time. As always, gym users should wipe down the equipment before and after they have used it, with the products provided."All swimming pools will consist of wider lanes and group tanks, with maximum numbers in place and a fixed swim session of  minutes plus  minutes for changing. Swimmers must follow the lanersquos one-way system."They will be able to change in the changing rooms before they swim however, we request that they arrive lsquoswim readyrsquo with costumes on under their clothes to speed up the changing process and get in the pool quicker."The capacity of fitness classes will be reduced to ensure people can space out from each other while exercising. All the equipment and the exercise area will be cleaned between classes."As a precaution, dry side changing rooms have been taken out of action and customers will be required to arrive dressed ready for their training session. Customer toilets, however, will be available."Mostof our childrenrsquos coached activity programmes will be resuming too. Childrenrsquos swimming lessons will restart from Monday, September , and classes within our gymnastics programme will resume from Monday, September . We are also adding a waiting listfor fitness classes and gym sessions."Alongside the booking of activities, we will be asking all customers and visitors to provide us with their name and contact details in support of the NHS Test and Protect scheme."All direct debit paying members will be contacted regarding the reopening of facilities and provided with details on the new booking and operational procedures in place. We will also advise them of the options available regarding their membership payments."We regret that not all facilities will be opening immediately. This includes the health suites , soft play areas and squash courts . Additionally, the cafe facilities will remain temporarily closed, although vending machines will be available."In the coming weeks, all of our centre colleagues will complete a comprehensive training induction on the new safety measures and cleaning regimes we are putting in place. In addition, they will be updated on the revised operational practices concerning le guarding duties, teaching swimming lessons and delivering gymnastics in line with guidance issued by RLSS, Scottish Swimming and Scottish Gymnastics."The centre opening times currently scheduled for September  are:Bill Axon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, said: ldquoI would like to take this opportunity to thank all of our customers for their continued loyalty and support. We are incredibly grateful for all of the messages of encouragement received.ldquoI would also like to extend my gratitude and appreciation to all enjoyleisure colleagues that have been working incredibly hard behind the scenes."Their tireless efforts have been instrumental in getting us to this point, which has included completely redefining our cleaning and safety standards, and reorganising our activity areas to comply with physical distancing at all of our centres and swimming pools.ldquoOur objective is to welcome and allow as many of our customers as possible, to safely access our gyms, swimming pools, exercise classes, sports and leisure activities.ldquoI hope by re-opening all our six sites, enjoyleisure is demonstrating to our customers that we remain absolutely committed to meeting our communitiesrsquo needs and enable many to be more active, more often with all the health advantages that that brings."We are hopeful we will be able to gradually increase capacities in our facilities in a phased manner, thus providing a safe, controlled and well-managed sport, health and fitness offering, which will enable us to methodically re-build the use of our facilities.ldquoWe know that our customers will have a lot of questions concerning the reopening of our facilities. There is a lot to tell you, and we promise we will do so over the coming weeks. Please look out for updates arriving in your email inbox and or posted onto our website enjoyleisure and social media pages."

title: opinion-joanna-blythman-gene-editing-improve-food-sounds-good---become-public-health-nightmare
story: Despite the diplomatically opaque new name, gene editing is turbo-charged genetic engineering, only so far with better PR. Butthe free traders and corporate influencers in Westminster get their way and deregulate the law that currently governs genetic engineering there, gene edited foods could be green lighted, unlabelled, for English plates, so that most people wouldnrsquot realise that they were eating them.Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland would then be put under heavy international corporate pressure to do the same.Like the old guard, now stigmatised, genetically modiedfood before it, with its unhappy history of failures to deliver and creation of new problems, such as the creation of herbicide-resistant super-weeds, proponents of gene editing spin futuristic yarns about all the miracles theyrsquore rustling up for us.Less starchy potatoes and corn, pork from super-muscly pigs, spicy tomatoes, and mushrooms that resist browning, are some front runners. In fact the mushrooms have already bypassed US Department of Agriculture regulation.How can this second wave of genetically engineered foods be a realistic prospect when the first lot were so unpopular in the UK and the EU that the general public shunned them Proponents claim that gene editing is a precise, safe technology with predictable outcomes. Sound familiar  They say that theyrsquore only making very small changes to the genetic make-up of foods, merely mimicking what might happen through natural mutation.Tellingly, they seek patents for these altered foods. Patents are only grantedyou can show an inventive step that is man-made. So claims that gene editing is simply causing changes that could happen naturally go out the window.Donrsquot worry, though, they assure us that gene editing carries no more risk than conventional breeding. In fact, there is no evidence to support this blaseacute assertion because no feeding studies have been carried out in either humans or animals.Along with scientists from around the world, I attended a briefing on gene editing led by the London-based molecular geneticist Dr Michael Antoniou. It left me deeply concerned. He flagged up the growing body of gold standard scientic research that highlights the unintended and potentially dangerous risks that gene edited foods pose. Far from being precise and predictable, these lab-based, articial interventions damage plant or animal DNA, not just at the intended site of the genetic alteration, but where.For instance, it emerged last year that a hornless bull gene edited by a Minnesota company was unintentionally contaminated by bacterial genes from another species. https:www.technologyreview     recombinetics-gene-edited-hornless-cattle-major-dna-screwup Gene editing alters how genes , which can create new allergens and toxins. The European Network of Scientists for Social and Environmental Responsibility ndash  leading international scientists ndash has expressed grave concerns. They say that the radical nature of gene edited changes could result in ldquounexpectedly high levels of known toxins, or even in the creation of novel ones.So, the bottom line here is that therersquos a push to slip gene edited food ingredients into our food, unlabelled, most likely sneakily lost in multi-ingredient, ultra-processed foods, on the assumption that they pose no risk. So far, the general public is blissfully unaware of it.To ensure public safety and the integrity of the food we eat, its absolutely vital that all ingredients from gene edited crops, plants, or farm animals, be subjected to risk assessment of the most stringent nature.These novel creations must be tightly regulated, with track and trace systems in place so that in the case of a genetically engineered public health disaster, retailers can put out effective product recalls.Most crucially, gene edited food must be clearly labelled as genetically modied so that we can choose for ourselveswersquore prepared to eat it. I donrsquot know about you, but Irsquom not.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: open-culture-maybe-cake-10-museums-back-business
story: While we are still under the shadow of the virus, some things are beginning to come back, museums among them. The last few days has seen the reopening of both the National Museum of Scotland and Kelvingrove Museum. More will follow this coming week. And while access is controlled and there are limitations on where you can go, after months in lockdown the chance to visit your favourite museumis surely to be welcomed. Herersquos  you might like to visit soon. And remember to wear that mask when yoursquore indoors.National Museum of Scotland, EdinburghReopened on Wednesday on reduced hours , the National Museum of Scotland is once again the perfect retreat for those seeking refuge from the temperamental Edinburgh weather. Pre-booked timed entry, mandatory face coverings and one-way routes are all now in operation as the museum tries totonormal. Entrance will be by the west door on Chambers Street.The museumrsquos reopening will be phased in. The entrance hall and level one are now open to visitors, but rooms with a high number of interactive displays, including the Imagine and Explore galleries, remain closed for the moment.Inevitably, the museum has had to postpone a number of special exhibitions, but it is home to Scotlandrsquos Precious Seas, an exhibition that explores the nationrsquos erse sea le and the effect climate change is having on our maritime environment. Itrsquos part of the Year of Coasts and Waters.Visit nms.ac.uk for more details and to book entryKelvingrove Museum, GlasgowPre-booking is also required for Kelvingrove which has reopened its doors to the public from am to pm daily. Tickets will be available up to two weeks in advance, with a maximum of six visitors for each booking, all from the same family. Entry will be timed and will allow visitors a two-hour slot. A one-way system has been introduced, but most of the main gallery spaces are open. Masks are required and there will be no catering facilities. But the toilets are open. Entrance is by the carpark side.That only leaves one question. Whatrsquos the first thing yoursquore going to visit when you get back in  Are you there for the ancient Egyptian artefacts or for a catch-up with the work of Charles Rennie Mackintosh PS, the Riverside Museum is reopening on August . Put it in your diary.For more information and to book tickets, visit glasgowmuseumsNational Museum of Flight, East FortuneBooking in advance for timed entry is required for the National Museum of Flight in East Fortune. But at least you donrsquot need to self-quarantine when you get off the planes here. Some buildings are still closed unfortunately, but the Concorde Experience, the Parachute Store and the civil and military aviation hangars are all open, as well as the shop and cafe. One-way routes are in use.And, of course, the airfield itself is open, which means you can have a look inside the planes ndash therersquos a Vulcan, a Comet and a BAC - ndash on display. No passports required.Visit nms.ac.uk national-museum-of-flightfor details and bookings.The McManus art gallery and museum, DundeeNamed Scotlandrsquos best visitor attraction not long before lockdown, the McManus reopened on Thursday and remains one of the most reliable boltholes in Dundee .Now open daily from Tuesday to Saturday, am to pm, there is no booking necessary and exhibitions are free. The cafeacute has reopened with social distancing measures and the shop will only allow four customers at a time. Entry numbers to the museum will also be limited so you might have to queue.Joseph McKenzies photography at the McManusStill, it will be worth it. To celebrate its reopening, two new exhibitions have just opened. Time and Tide: The Transformation of the Tay looks at the importance of the river in the continuing story of the city, while A Love Letter to Dundee: Joseph McKenzie Photographs - celebrates McKenziersquos evocative and nostalgic black and white images of Dundee as it once was.Visit mcmanusfor more detailsVA Dundee, DundeeStill a few days to wait. The VA reopens its doors on Thursday. Pre-booked timed entry is now required, and social distancing measures and one-way systems have been introduced. But on the plus side the Tatha restaurant will reopen, as will the shop. As the ground floor cafeacute has closed, the Tatha will also offer cafe and takeaway options.And along with the regular galleries, the museum reopens with a new exhibition celebrating the work of Mary Quant, the first international retrospective of the revolutionary fashion designer. As far as we know wearing a mini skirt is not a requirement for entrance. Just as well. Some of us donrsquot have the legs for it.If yoursquore really keen, of course, you could double up with a trip to the Dovecot Studios in Edinburgh where the current exhibition Mid-Century Modern also focuses on Quant along with Terence Conran.Visit vam.ac.uk dundee to book ticketsThe Stirling Smith Art Gallery and Museum, StirlingAh, The Smith. There is no museum in Scotland Irsquove spent more time in over the years. Having just reopened, it will now be accessible from Thursday to Sunday, am to pm, with a one-way system in operation. No booking necessary.The Stirling Story exhibition continues to occupy its main exhibition space. Artist and collector Thomas Stuart Smith bequeathed his own work and collection to the museum and it forms the heart of The Man Who Could Paint Anything: The Legacy of Thomas Stuart Smith in gallery two, supplemented by donations by subsequent benefactors. The work of Anne Redpath, William McTaggart and William Gillies are all represented in the exhibition. Paul Eamesrsquo The Power of Flight, meanwhile, continues in gallery one until September .Even better news. The Smith Cafe has also reopened. The Sunday afternoons spent eating cake there hellipVisit smithartgalleryandmuseumfor more informationPerth Museum and Art Gallery, PerthPerths Discovering Egypt exhibitionAdvanced booking is required for ato Perth which has also introduced timed entries and a new one-way system.As well as all the usual attractions, Perth offers a number of exhibitions, including ICONS II: John Bellany and Conservation in Action. Discovering Ancient Egypt continues until October . And, of course, therersquos New Ways of Seeing: Scottish Art Schools, drawn from the museumrsquos permanent collection, which contains work by the likes of Joan Eardley, Anne Redpath, John Byrne and Sir Robin Philipson.The museumrsquos opening hours are Monday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday from am to .pm and pm to pm, and Thursday from .pm to .pm.Visit cultureperthandkinross.arttickets.org.uk to book tickets and for more informationScottish Fisheries Museum, AnstrutherWednesday is the day for the reopening of Anstrutherrsquos Scottish Fisheries Museum. Pre-booked timed entry and one-way routes through the museum will be in operation, with card payments only in the cafe and shop. Summer opening hours, which cover Wednesday to Sunday, am to pm, continue until the end of October.If you havenrsquot visited before, the museum has  boats and an extensive collectionof maritime artefats, photographs and paintings.It also must be one of the best situated museums for anyone wanting to top up with a fish supper afterwards.Visit scotfishmuseum.orgfor more informationRobert Burns Birthplace Museum, AllowayA substantial number of National Trust for Scotland properties have now reopened, including the Robert Burns Birthplace Museum in Alloway, which is open Thursday to Monday, from am to .pm. Entry offers access not only to the museum but to the cottage where the Bard was born. And as the cottage was rethatched and restored just before lockdown this may be the best time to see it.For more information visit nts.org.uk visit places robert-burns-birthplace-museum.Jim Clark Motorsport Museum, DunsThis Borders museum celebrates the le and achievements of one of Scotlandrsquos greatest sportsmen Jim Clark, twice Formula  world champion, who tragically died in  on the track at Hockenheim.The museum is home to the Lotus Cortina in which Clark won the  British Saloon Car Championship and a Lotus Type , one of the most iconic Formula  cars, driven by Clark in  Grands Prix between  and .For the moment, the museum is only open on Monday,Fridays and Saturdays between am and pmSundays from pm to pm. Numbers are limited, and advance booking is required.Visit for more details and to book jimclarktrust jim-clark-motorsport-museum

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  Why marriage is becoming as middle class as owning an Aga
story: The CSJ is a centre-right think tank co-founded in  by former Tory Party leader Iain Duncan Smith to help tackle poverty and family breakdown. The leader of its family policy unit is Cristina Odone, former editor of The Catholic Herald. As such its , among others, is to shore up classic Conservative family values, at the heart of which is marriage. Sadly, the present Prime Minister seems not to have received the memo.Setting aside for the moment the religious and political leanings of those behind this report, its conclusions show the stark and widening gulf between the married well-off and the unmarried poor. Medicine has long recognised the advantages ndash especially to men ndash of tying the knot, but the CSJrsquos findings focus on the enormous benefit that marriage bestows not on the couple, but on their children.Despite being lauded by David Cameron as ldquoa great institution, few subjects have been more ripe for ridicule. The butt of stand-ups down the ages, matrimony is the gag that never stops giving. It can be plumbed endlessly for laughs by the cynical, the wry, the embittered and the romantic. Yet the conclusions of the Centre for Social Justicersquos report are anything but funny.Their statistics show that those on low incomes are far less keen to wed than the wealthy. Once children are born, cohabiting parents are almost four times more likely to separate before a child is five than married parents. The health and educational attainment of children with broken family backgrounds are worse, and their likelihood of having a criminal conviction by the age of  doublestheir parents separated before they were five.These statistics certainly cast matrimony in a starkly black and white light. And it gets worse. The middle classes are not only more likely to marry, but % of high earners do so, compared to % of the poorest. If a straight line can be drawn between cohabitation and unstable family relationships, that is bad news for youngsters from disadvantaged backgrounds. Butmarriage truly is the key factor in this downward trajectory,a set of vows and a certicate and a wedding video is the glue that holds the middle classes together, then that is a whole other issue. Suddenly a custom that previously was prevalent across the classes is in danger of becoming a status symbol. Marriage, by this calculation, is synonymous with money.I grew up in the wake of the Beatles and the moon landing, when walking down the aisle was no longer essential, evenyou hoped to have children. Nevertheless the stigma of cohabiting, or becoming parents before you wore a wedding ring, took a long time to fade. When finally it became commonplace society grew more civilised, acknowledging that couples didnrsquot require an official document to take themselves, and be taken, seriously. Cohabiting was no more a byword for casual than marrying was for happy. Yet now, it is deemed a red flag for social disadvantage.The direct correlation between marriage and class suggests that money is at least part of the explanation. Those who are strapped for cash either consider it irrelevant, or not for the likes of them. And the more it is perceived to be for the better off, the less it will appeal to people further down the social spectrum.You canrsquot help wonderingthe wedding industry, as opposed to marriage itself, has created expectations that the hard-up simply cannot meet. With the average Scottish wedding now costing over a staggering pound,, this comes as no surprise. Increasingly the concept of marrying is bound up with the wedding. The status of the couple and their families is proclaimed by the nature of the ceremony, the wedding venue, and the sumptuousness of the reception. Not to mention stag and hen weekends and parties beforehand.It takes at least a year, and usually a lot longer, to book, plan and save for the big day. Ultimately, though, what matters is not the trappings, but making the vows, whether in a religious setting, or a registry office. The seriousness of the bond lies in the couplersquos decision to commit to each other, not in any of the hoopla that follows. Perhaps it is time to separate the legal procedure from the carnival that follows, to consciously uncouple the act of union from this crippling cost.Yet the nub of the problem identied by CSJ is not marriage itself, but hardship. Those living on the bread line do not have the resources, and possibly donrsquot have the inclination, to get officially tied. Given the serious disadvantages suffered when they separate, the answer, surely, is not to coax iniduals into wedlock, asit were the panacea for all their ails, but to digny cohabiting couples and their offspring with the same legal safeguards and tax breaks as those who marry. Protecting the rights of children and parents ndash especially mothers, who commonly look after the kids once a relationship ends ndash would give them a financial safety-net. Many of the outcomes for youngsters described in this report ndash gang membership, criminality, mental and physical health issues ndash are as much the result of penury as the lack of a piece of paper supposedly binding their parents forever.If it is to retain its meaning, marriage has to be a personal choice, not a virtuous act that deserves a reward. It can be done cheaply and quietly, as I can testy, or with terric fanfare, or it can be avoided altogether. Either way, in an enlightened world those in long-term relationships, and couples with children, should be treated by government in exactly the same way as the married. Until that day ndash far off, I fear ndash the gulf between the haves and the have nots will steadily deepen, eroded by a judgemental, moralising and, as wersquove too often seen, hypocritical state.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter  True blue Tories wondering how they voted Boris but got Corbyn
story: How long ago that seems. Tory commentators and many MPs are deeply dischuffed with Mr Johnson, and not just because his Government made an even worse cock-up of the exams than the Scottish Government. Negotiations resumed this week over the withdrawal agreement with the European Union, and it is safe to say that expectations among the Conservative faithful are not high.Indeed, Brexiter Tory MPs, like Iain Duncan Smith, fully expect a sell-out. They think Mr Johnson is preparing to accept a whole range of EU regulations even after we have left. This means no trade deals with free market America, no state aid to key industries, no low tax havens and a ldquobetrayal of fishing.Tory MPs hoped that Boris would be tough on immigration, would cut taxes and rein back bureaucracy, while tackling political correctness and the nanny state. What they got was a bicycling PM who seems to be tough on motorists, not illegals. He has adopted what the Spectator columnist Christopher Snowden, calls ldquopurse-lipped, micro-managing, finger-wagging, lemon-sucking, censorious, anti-business, killjoy policies like the campaigns on obesity and sugar.Not in their wildest dreams did true blue Tories expect their chosen one to increase public spending by more than any Labour government since . Yet, this Government is currently paying the wages of half the working population through furlough, benefits and public sector employment. UK debt is now pound trillion. Thank God Margaret Thatcher is not alive to see it.Mr Johnson hasnrsquot even delivered on scrapping HS, the fast rail line that most Tory MPs think is a white elephant. Instead, he is fantasising about building bridges between Scotland and Northern Ireland. Yet that is not going to keep the Union together. His Brexit deal, it is now clear, has created a gulf between the UK and Northern Ireland.The province has remained in regulatory alignment with the European Unionrsquos single market, which means that there must be the very border checks the PM promised would never happen. Worse, it has handed the SNP a genuine grievance: being denied access to markets with which Northern Ireland can trade seamlessly.Tories are appalled by Mr Johnsonrsquos lack of urgency on Scotland as support for independence grows. The former Tory leader, William Hague, said this week thatthe PM doesnrsquot get his act together the UK will be finished within five years. Tories like Mr Hague think he allowed Nicola Sturgeon to play politics with the coronavirus.What they didnrsquot anticipate was the cack-handed and contradictory approach taken by the UK Government. At first, the lockdown seemed to appeal to the British wartime spirit, which always goes down well on the Right. But far from winning a victory over this viral enemy, Britain has recorded the worst excess death rate in Europe and now the deepest recession.Most Conservatives loath the imposition of masks, which the Daily Mail commentator, Peter Hitchens, calls ldquomuzzles, and which libertarians think are pointless impediments. Many Tory voters spend their holidays in France and the letters columns are full of people complaining about being forced back to Blighty even from regions of France where Covid is almost non-existent.Yet this Conservative Government kept Britainrsquos airports open during the worst phase of the pandemic, allowing  million travellers to come to Britain largely unchecked, including a number from Covid hot spots like Italy and China. And donrsquot even mention track and trace.The exams debacle was the final straw. Tory MPs want the head of the Education Secretary, Gavin Williamson, on a plate for his chaotic U-turn, but the real criticism is of the Prime Minister. He should surely have seen this coming after the chaos in Scotland. It seems to many asMr Johnson isnrsquot really in charge.His presentation has been lamentable, and even is greatest fans are disappointed with his bumbling delivery and lack of grip. He was never a detail man, and everyone knew he flew by the seat of his pants ndash thatrsquos when he managed to keep them on.Conservatives are pretty forgiving to politicians who think like they do, have the same instincts on nation and values. What is especially damaging is a growing sense that Mr Johnson is just not really a Conservative at all. They expected him to take a tough line with the statue topplers and culture warriors of Black Lives Matters. But instead of banging heads, he avoided confrontation and made only a routine condemnation of vandalism. He allowed Winston Churchill himself to be boxed up in Parliament Square. How could it come to this Part of the problem, I think, is that many Conservatives believed what Labour said about Mr Johnson ndash that he was a bit of a racist, misogynist, homophobic right winger. The most ldquoright-wing prime minister in British history as Labourrsquos John Mc Donnell called him. This he never was.Colourful phrases about Burqa-wearers looking like letter boxes does not a white supremacist make. When he was London mayor, he was careful to keep the black and ethnic community onside and he used to lead LGBT marches wearing a pink stetson. When he became PM he installed more BAME ministers than all previous UK governments combined. You wont hear Mr Johnson using Daily Mail rhetoric about immigrants, he genuinely believes in state intervention and he is quietly a bit of a Europhile. Far from being a free market ideologue, Boris Johnson is a liberal, patrician Tory ndash more like Michael Heseltine, Brexit aside, than Margaret Thatcher.The final insult was this Tory Prime Minister ennobling Claire Fox, a former Revolutionary Communist who used to support the objectives of the IRA. That was the final straw. As the Tory commentator Brian Monteith put it, many Conservatives now feel that they ldquovoted Boris and got Corbyn.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The HeraldRead more: Opinion: Iain Macwhirter: UK beats the world alright: in Covid deaths and lost jobs
