title: ‘Common sense’ A levels U turn
story: AS GCSE students across the district prepare to receive their grades tomorrow, schools across the district have given their reaction to the U-turn over awarding AS and A-Level results.Head teachers believe that while many students had already secured the grades that they required, Stormont education minister Peter Weir made the right decision in the end by confirming that students who have not been in class since March and not sat formal exams will receive the highest grades awarded to them by either teachers or their exams body.Mr Joe McCann, principal at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick, said he was heartened that the distress, confusion and anxiety created last Thursday had been eased.But he said this brought new challenges for students who may have missed out on university places last week and that the school was working to support them in the days ahead.ldquoI would like to pay particular tribute to the work of the Secondary School Students Union of Northern Ireland who were instrumental in informing public opinion and lobbying political leaders with a relentless commitment to ensuring justice for all post- students throughout Northern Ireland, said Mr McCann.ldquoI believe that the power of student voice was instrumental in the lead up to the decision to award the lsquobest gradersquo to students. I am very proud that our incoming head boy, Cormac Savage, was at the forefront of this campaign and believe his contribution was pivotal in ensuring that the sense of injustice and unfairness felt by his peers was articulated in a forceful and timely manner.Mr McCann also welcomed confirmation that GCSE grades will be awarded as calculated by schools.ldquoTeachers were asked to exercise professional judgment and engaged in a robust process to ensure that pupil effort and attainment in the period from September  to the unexpected and unprecedented closing of schools in March was rewarded, he said. ldquoA great deal of time and energy was devoted to this task by the staff of St. Patrickrsquos Grammar to ensure that grades were awarded fairly and consistently.Down High principal Maud Perry, said after the initial publication of results last Thursday the school was celebrating its best ever A-Level achievements.ldquoThis was unsurprising, as this particular year group achieved the schoolrsquos best ever AS results last year, she said.ldquoThis was a very dferent year in so many ways, but Down High pupils continue to be among the best qualied of their generation and, beyond the curriculum, our pupils are enriched, socially confident and ready to take their place as leaders of the future in whatever fields they choose. Congratulations to all of the pupils on these fully deserved grades.Shimna Integrated College principal Kevin Lambe congratulated the schoolrsquos ldquowonderful A level students who weathered the storm of this unprecedented year.He said he was delighted that the vast majority of students had already been placed at their first choice of university before the restoration of the teacher assessed grades on Monday afternoon.Mr Lambe said that while there had been considerable controversy about the process of awarding grades this year, he paid tribute to the excellent guidance document CCEA provided and to the commitment and energy his staff brought to the grading process.ldquoI am quite sure that the moderation process was undertaken in good faith, but it caused dreadful damage and heartache across the country, he said. ldquoThe CCEA guidance was sound, the work of teachers was thoroughgoing, the teacher awarded grades were the right ones and I am absolutely delighted that they have been restored.Ballynahinchrsquos Assumption Grammar School said it was delighted with the government U-turn in awarding grades as the original process ldquocaused signicant emotional upheaval which affected students, parents and our staff.ldquoWe are fortunate in that over % of our A students had already accessed their chosen university or workplace and hope that now almost every girl has achieved their true potential and will be able to access a iety of career pathways. Assumption Girls set the highest of standards year on year and we are proud of our Year  Girls who excelled in every subject at every level, said a school statement.ldquoOur AS students now have a solid foundation of grades which will give them the confidence to believe in their own potential to achieve at the highest of levels as they enter A level. We wish our GCSE girls the best of luck for tomorrowrsquos results.Castlewellanrsquos St Malachyrsquos High School said it was pleased with Education Minister Peter Weirrsquos announcement that AS and A level students will receive their centre assessment grades or the grade awarded by the examining body, whichever is higher.ldquoWe continue to work hard in St Malachyrsquos in the best interests of all our young people, said a statement issued on Monday evening. We are all here in St Malachyrsquos to help and support our students in the best way we can. Congratulations on their wonderful achievements we wish them all the very best in the future.De La Salle High School principal Ciaran Maguire described the past academic year for students as ldquochallenging.He said students adhered to social distancing guidelines collecting their results last Thursday, with the school delighted with their overall grades.ldquoA-Level results across the province has been one of confusion and uncertainty, said Mr Maguire.ldquoWe as a school were relieved that the majority of the teacher assessment grades were secured for our pupils and will continue to appeal and challenge those that need to be addressed to ensure that all pupils get the right outcome, allowing them to progress in an ever changing world.Before Mondayrsquos announcement, Mr Mark Morgan, principal at St Colmanrsquos High and Sixth Form College in Ballynahinch, said the continued year on year improvement in grades from the students appeared to have been curtailed by the examination bodies.He said teacher predicted grades, which were in line with all the tracking data, appeared to have been totally ignored and grades were given that bore no reflection to the historic and contemporaneous standard attained by students at the school.St Maryrsquos High School in Downpatrick congratulated its A-Level and AS-Level students who received their results.The school said the studentsrsquo success was a ldquoreflection of their hard work, determination to succeed and dedicated teaching staff who always go the extra mile.ldquoOur steady, upward trend in examination results has continued this year and we wish our students all the very best as they begin their studies at university, the statement added..prettyPhoto

title: 53 dogs put down in past year – one third of all in NI
story: A LOCAL politician says she is ldquoheartbroken that more dogs being put to sleep in Newry, Mourne and Down than any other council area in Northern Ireland.Fty-three dogs were destroyed in Newry, Mourne and Down in - out of a total of  for the whole province.Thatrsquos almost twice as many as the next highest area, which is Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon with .By contrast six councils reported single figure death rates, while not a single dog was put to sleep in Ards and North Down.Rowallane area councillor Kathryn Owen says the figure for Newry, Mourne and Down makes for ldquogrim reading.Cllr Owen, who has four dogs, says the council should look to the successful measures being implemented in other council areas.ldquoTo say Irsquom heartbroken about the immense number of dogs destroyed in Newry, Mourne and Down District would be an understatement, she said.ldquoThis is not a statistic that we should be proud of. We are nearly double that of the next lowest council. Six councils are in single figures, and there is no reason why we at Newry, Mourne and Down should be any worse.ldquoI have four dogs of my own, three of which are rescues, and as a huge animal lover this shatters me.ldquoI fully appreciate that there are some dogs that are unsuitable for rehoming due to aggression or illness, but I fail to understand why we have had to destroy  in one year mdash thatrsquos almost one a week.Cllr Owen says she has had a ldquoconstructive conversation with the councilrsquos head of licensing and enforcement and asked for a dialogue to begin with other councils.ldquoIt would be helpful to see what we can learn and implement in our district in the future, she continued.ldquoThere is no need for us to reinvent the wheelother councils are already being successful, we should follow their model.She added: ldquoI would like to recognise the hard work done by Ards and North Down Council in conjunction with Lost and Found Pets North Down Ards Rescue and Rehoming.A spokesman for Newry, Mourne and Down Council said it worked closely with animal welfare colleagues in the management of its dog control service.He said the council received a total of  unwanted and stray dogs between April  and March .ldquoThis is the second largest total of dogs received across all Northern Ireland councils over this reporting period, he said.ldquoWhile recognising the figure for the destruction of dogs appears high, the council have reduced the number of dogs humanely destroyed over this period, from  in ,  in  to  in .The spokesman added: ldquoNewry, Mourne and Down Council promotes responsible dog ownership and through public awareness it is hoped that this will further reduce the number of dogs sent for humane destruction in the future..prettyPhoto

title: Alan shares his love of wide open spaces%2C travel and sports
story: A LIFETIME ago Ballynahinch Camera Club vice-chairman Alan Chowney thought he would continue with his love of painting, which he first practiced in school.Alanrsquos artistic efforts did not always capture what he wanted to show, despite many hoursrsquo work, and so he drted away from painting with the intention of ing to it in later le.When he started his working career he got seriously interested in cameras. Then with work colleagues he discovered developing and printing photographs mdash and became hooked.He says: ldquoFor over  years my interests were framed in the many photographs I took mdash my love of wide open spaces, wildle, sports, aircraft and the chance to travel which offered unlimited opportunities.ldquoWith the introduction of digital photography, suddenly I could take thousands of photographs and applying camera technique and a bit of imagination, I document the world as I saw it. My paint brushes have remained in their box.Alan joined Ballynahinch Camera Club in  in preparation for retirement.ldquoThe experience of working with many talented photographers helped me to improve my images by introducing dferent techniques and ways of looking at the scene, he says.ldquoNow I can share my obsession with others and enjoy their company each Thursday night and on outdoor trips across Ireland.ldquoHopefully, these photographs will give some sense of my enjoyment of this hobby. Many reflect locations in Co Down where I grew up and was introduced to my other passion mdash fishing. But that is another story..prettyPhoto

title: Belfast aquarium proposal could ‘devastate’ Exploris
story: A STORMONT minister has been asked to allow her department to determine a planning application for a proposed poundm aquarium at Belfastrsquos Titanic Quarter and not leave the decision to city councillors.The appeal to Department for Infrastructure minister Nichola Mallon has been made by Strangford MLA Kellie Armstrong who is concerned about the ldquodevastating impact the multi-million pound proposal will have on the Exploris aquarium in Portaferry.Six years ago, the future of the local aquarium and visitor facility was under threat, but a major campaign supported by the community and politicians secured financial backing for a much-needed makeover at the tourist attraction which is crucial to the economy on both sides of the internationally acclaimed waterway.Ms Armstrong urged Mrs Mallon to lsquocall inrsquo the planning application for the proposed Belfast aquarium which those behind the project estimate could attract as many as , visitors each year,planning approval is secured.If Ms Mallon agrees to call in the application, it will take the decision away from Belfast City Council.Ms Armstrong ndash who was heavily involved in the Save Exploris campaign a few years ago ndash saidthe Titanic Quarter aquarium is allowed to proceed, ldquoit would devastate the local tourism sector in the Ards peninsula.And she encouraged local people to make their concerns heard by objecting to the planning application prior to last nightrsquos meeting of Belfast City Council.ldquoThere is absolutely no necessity for another aquarium in Northern Ireland, especially when we already have an excellent facility on the Ards peninsula, the MLA declared.ldquoIf this planning application is allowed to progress it will have a signicant detrimental economic impact on the existing Exploris aquarium in Portaferry, on the rural village of Portaferry and tourism in general on the rural Ards peninsula.Ms Armstrong said Belfast City Council was expected to pass the planning application ldquowithout appreciating the signicant impact the development will have in another council area.She said this was why the infrastructure minister must call in the application before it proceeds any further.ldquoThis particular planning application has regional signicance and a detrimental impact on a rural area, the MLA added.ldquoThatrsquos why I have written to Minister Mallon to press the case of all those whose livelihoods depend on the tourism impact of the Exploris. The Minister cannot allow all this to simply be thrown away.Ms Armstrong said the local community previously stood together to save Exploris and would do so again.She added: ldquoI would urge anyone with concerns to make their voice heard and lodge their concerns and together we can save our local economy.It is believed that the poundm aquarium proposal for Belfast could create more than  full-time jobs and would be the biggest attraction of its kind on the island of Ireland, with city planners recommending that the new development should be given the green light.The firm behind it, reefLIVE, says around  to  jobs could be created during its construction, with  full-time posts created when it opens its doors, subject to securing planning approval.The aquarium would be a two-storey building, based across more than , sq ft and include a cafe, coral reef ocean tank, with the main exhibition space across five zones on the first floor ndash themed as Ireland, Deep Ocean, Azores, Pacic and Arctic.Around  representations were received in relation to the planning application, including  letters of objection.Concerns included the impact to traffic and travel, the impact on heritage for both listed buildings and monuments, flooding and the potential negative impact on the Exploris aquarium in Portaferry.Those behind the planned tourist attraction say it is anticipated the reefLIVE Aquarium will be the largest marine-le visitor attraction on the island of Ireland and in bringing another international-standard attraction to the Titanic Quarter, would help to boost theof tourist visits to the city.In recommending the scheme for approval, Belfast City Council planners said that ldquohaving regard to the development plan and other material considerations, including the issues raised by the representation, the proposal is considered and approval of planning permission is recommended with delegated authority given to the director of planning and building control to finalise the wording of conditions subject to no new substantive planning issues being raised by third parties..prettyPhoto

title: Celebrations to mark the end of WW2
story: CHURCH bells rang out across Killyleagh on Saturday morning to mark the th anniversary of VJ Day.The bells of St Johnrsquos Church of Ireland were tolled as part of the UK-wide commemorations of the anniversary.The day when the Second World War finally ended was celebrated with a short interdenominational act of remembrance at the War Memorial.At am former Army chaplain Hector Wanliss gave a ure reading and led prayers of thanksgiving for the men of Killyleagh, Shrigley and district who went to war, and for peace.Then Last Post and Reveille were sounded by Ronnie Cromie and Wilmer Cromie before two minutesrsquo silence was observed and Binyonrsquos Lines were recited by Billy Croskery, the chairman of Killyleagh and Killinchy Royal British Legion.A wreath was then laid by Mr Croskery, who was escorted by Kevin Kelly.Sadly Killyleaghrsquos last remaining Second World War veteran, Martin `Tinarsquo Charters, who is aged , was not able to take part on this occasion.Social distancing measures were in place and the organisers are grateful for those who attended adhering to these.It was a timely reminder that the main highlight of the year, the Killyleagh VE  celebrations, had to be cancelled in May by the Killyleagh Remembers the War group in the wake of the Coronavirus alert and the danger of public gatherings.The Killyleagh group has now cancelled its next proposed event, a lecture on the Second World War in the library due to be given by author George Busby on September .ldquoWe will be keeping under review the remaining schedule of the programme, in conjunction with the Heritage Lottery Fund. The Busby lecture is cancelled and we will re-evaluate the planned events for the rest of , giving priority to the health and well-being of those taking part, explained a spokesman for the group.The production of a film featuring Killyleaghrsquos dfering roles in the - war is continuing. It is hoped to show this in Killyleagh on Remembrance weekend.The th anniversary of VJ Day was also commemorated in Ballynahinch on Saturday.Members of the local Royal British Legion branch gathered at the townrsquos War Memorial at am for a short wreath laying ceremony.The wreath was laid by Dr Fred Byrne, chairman of the branch, who also recited Binyonrsquos Lines.South Down MLA Harry Harvey was among those attending the commemoration..prettyPhoto

title: Council overwhelmed by volunteers’ support throughout pandemic
story: THE efforts of community volunteers across the district who delivered food parcels during the coronavirus pandemichave been praised by local politicians.During  weeks of shielding, a total of , food boxes were delivered with the assistance of  organisations and iniduals throughout the council area. In the busiest week, , food boxes were delivered to the most vulnerable residents.In addition to food parcels being delivered, isolated residents received medical supplies and the opportunity for social connection.People from ious groups helped deliver parcels at the height of the pandemic with many unable to leave their homes due to a iety of reasons.The efforts of those who worked alongside Newry, Mourne and Down Council to deliver essential items to those in need have been praised by local authority chairwoman Laura Devlin and Rowallane DEA chairwoman Kathryn Owen.They have both highlighted the efforts of the community and voluntary sectors, sporting bodies and members of the public who rose to the challenge of Covid-.Praising all concerned, the council chairwoman said that when faced with the ldquocomplex and challenging issues of protecting the most vulnerable and isolated residents, the local authority was ldquooverwhelmed by the support it was offered.ldquoOn behalf of the council I wish to offer my sincere thanks to all who provided assistance in our time of crisis and for all that you have done to ensure our most vulnerable residents were kept safe, said Cllr Devlin. ldquoThe contributions made by all have been truly remarkable.ldquoAs restrictions are eased, the council wishes everyone a safe and enjoyable summer confident in the knowledge that we have the capacity to work in partnership and face any new challenges in the coming months with confidence.The council chairwoman said the organisation is also encouraging people to play their part by continuing to follow government guidelines to reduce the risk of transmission.Cllr Owen said that with the help of Down Community Transport and local community groups, more than  food parcels were delivered weekly over the shielding period across Rowallane.She said volunteers from local community groups not only delivered food parcels, but also collected and delivered preions and groceries for those shielding and provided befriending services, describing the community response as ldquoenthusiastic and invaluable during the Covid response.ldquoWithout hesitation during the pandemic, local community groups immediately offered any help they could to protect those most vulnerable in our area, explained Cllr Owen.ldquoThese volunteers willingly gave up precious family time to respond effectively and quickly to the emerging crisis. I wish to thank each and every inidual involved and acknowledge that we could not have managed an effective response without their help.Cllr Owen said the Rowallane DEA Forum has continued to deliver for its residents, conducting Skype meetings to ensure the identied priorities in the district continue to be responded to effectively.ldquoThe Forum is actively working on finding creative methods of engaging and delivering to our community, such as the development of a range of activities with the Clanrye Group for families and iniduals that are being delivered virtually.Cllr Owen added: ldquoRowallane DEA would like to pay tribute not only to the volunteers, but to each and every Rowallane Forum member who helped respond effectively to Covid-, often out of office hours and at weekends.ldquoThey have demonstrated their genuine commitment to making le better in Rowallane for each resident and visitor. We face challenging times ahead but I feel sure, having worked so effectively as a team during this recent crisis, that we are well placed to meet them..prettyPhoto

title: Drama pupils enjoy online summer fun
story: PUPILS from Mourne Stars Speech and Drama in Newcastle have taken part in an exciting four-week programme over the summer holidays.They logged on every Thursday to take part in lots fun and active lessons to enjoy before theirto school.The kids thoroughly enjoyed it and each week they played games, performed poetry, s and enjoyed some stories to help their creative imagination.Some of the themes for each week included puppetry, creating our own cooking shows, Tic Tok dancing, Mime, Going on Adventures, time travelling and many many more.Parents were keen to thank teacher Clare Murnin for the summer scheme and have loved seeing their children taking part.ldquoThe kids certainly looked forward each week to see what fun activities they would be taking part in, Clare said.ldquoSome of the comments that parents made were that their son or daughter improved in confidence, they got the opportunity to practice their literacy skills whilst off school and parents just loved watching them laugh and enjoy themselves each week.ldquoFor the final lesson, pupils took part in a fun fancy dress party and certainly used their imaginations to do so.ldquoIt was wonderful to see them all dressed up and making their characters come alive on screen in class. Many thanks to the parents for helping their children go to such a great effort!Clare is still making plans for the next term of Mourne Stars Speech and Drama. She hopes that regular classes will be up and running soon, butnot, they will definitely continue online via Zoom.To keep up to date, follow Mourne Stars Speech and Drama on Facebook and Instagram or send her an email to mournestars@gmail..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C August 16%2C 2000
story: SPA mdash Planning chiefs have this week been asked to defer making any decisions about new housing developments in the Spa area.The plea has been issued by local councillor Harvey Bicker in the wake of revelations that Water Service officials are having dficulty addressing a major sewage problem in the village.It is understood a number of homes are currently experiencing major dficulties getting rid of waste water and it is believed the problem is because their homes are below the level of the sewage treatment plant in Spa.Mr Bicker said Water Service officials are addressing the problem in a bid to come up with a solution and says that until they have completed their work, no new homes should be constructed in the Spa area.He revealed that  new homes are already in the pipeline and fears once they have been constructed, they will exacerbate the sewage problem.Mr Bicker said he has every sympathy for the Water Services engineers currently working to resolve what he described as a ldquoparticularly dficult problem.NEWCASTLE mdash The future of Newcastle Chamber of Commerce is under threat because a shortage of funding may rob the body of its long-serving secretary.Chamber officials believe it will be extremely dficult for the body to continue to exist in any meaningful way without the services of Maria Cunningham, who has worked for the group on a full-time basis for the past seven years.And to further compound the problem, a special Chamber meeting in the town on Monday night was attended by just nine out of its  membership, a turnout described as ldquowoeful by the president, Mr Peter Law.The disheartened president explained that a full-time secretary is needed to carry out vital work, and issued the blunt warning that he may resigncommitment to the Chamber does not improve.MURLOUGH mdash One of the arearsquos best loved natural attractions is to become the site of a major battle mdash against bracken and gorse.Murlough Nature Reserversquos rare duneland, near Dundrum, is being given a major environmental facelt at a cost of half a million pounds which will allow it to thrive into the st century and beyond.The local reserve is of international importance and home to one fth of all the dune heathland in Britain, a type of habitat which is rapidly disappearing and in need of protection.The drive to protect Murloughrsquos  acres of heathland and its species from being choked by larger invasive plants will include spraying and cutting back vegetation, grazing Exmoor ponies, and cutting and rolling grass.Entitled ldquoThe South Down Heathland Trust, the project was launched at a special gathering in Murlough House on Thursday afternoon attended by environmental experts and officials involved in the project, South Down MP, Eddie McGrady and South Down Assemblyman, Jim Wells.KILLYLEAGH mdash Roads Service officials have this week confirmed they plan to provide speed ramps at the Braeside Gardens housing estate in Killyleagh.The move comes after local community Billy Walker highlighted problems experienced by residents in the area.The entrance to Killyleaghrsquos new Bridge Centre is at the end of the local housing estate and the speed ramps are designed to slow the speed of vehicles in the area.Mr Walker said he is delighted Roads Service officials have agreed to provide the speed ramps and says the move will also be welcomed by residents in the Braeside Gardens area.ldquoThe residents are growing increasingly concerned about the speed of vehicles along a narrow street where cars can park on both sides, he said.ldquoVisibility for drivers is not great and the fact that speed ramps are to be provided to slow them down is very welcome indeed.DRUMANESS mdash A major new scheme aimed at improving safety levels in Drumaness is expected to get underway in the New Year.Roads Service officials met local councillors last week to explain details of the scheme and its implication for traffic management in the village.The safety scheme features a mini roundabout and a series of new road markings on the main approach roads designed to warn drivers to slow down as they enter Drumaness.A mini chicane between Cumber Grove and Cumber Grange is being proposed, while a large section of road outside the Gospel Hall will be painted red to encourage drivers to slow down.BALLYHORNAN mdash Ballyhornan could well become a jewel in Down Districtrsquos crown, but onlymajor improvements are carried out to local services and facilities.The village, whichwas centred around an RAF for over  years, but has, for some time, suffered a rapid decline in amenities.Three hundred people have moved to the area over the past four years and another housing development is on the cards leaving members of the local community association fearful the infrastructure will be unable to cope.The steady degeneration in local services from the area means residents are now forced to travel to Ardglass or Downpatrick for basic provisions, as well as collecting benefits, banking and medical needs.With a limited number of bus services running through the area, many are finding it hard to fit the journey in with their routine, forcing many, including young mothers with children, to pay for taxis or even walk to Ardglass for something as simple as a pint of milk.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A Ballynahinch man, who will die younghe does not lose weight, has pledged to shed  stones, and help Action MS along the way.Mark McMillan, who tips in on the scales at a sturdy  stones, has been warned by his doctor that the time has come to trim down.His current weight, according to Dr Richard Harrison, is cutting Markrsquos le expectancy by  years, pinpointing the need for a serious weight loss regime.While Mark has not set himself any tough targets, the  year-old will now seek local sponsorship as a means of spurring him on to achieve his ideal weight.The Ballynahinch Lions Club, whose chairman is Dr Harrison, has already stepped on board to offer Mark sponsorship and he hopes more support will follow.Dr Harrison admits that Mark has a hard job ahead of him.DOWNPATRICK mdash A Downpatrick teenager hoping to put Down District into the spotlight at next monthrsquos Wembley Horse of the Year show, is urging for assistance.Fteen year-old Paul Kaye was given the opportunity of a letime when his miniature horse, Minstrels Rocking Horse, was chosen to compete in the London show in June. But as preparations for the one-week event gets underway, Paul is beginning to realise the costs he faces.The teenager will need to raise pound, to fund the competition, including entrance fees, transport, stable shelter and injections for Minstrels Rocking Horse.Indeed, Paulrsquos father Jim, who has  miniature horses himself, says the costs of the Wembley show makes competing very dficult ldquofor the ordinary man.ARDGLASS mdash A very special anniversary will be celebrated in style in Ardglass next Wednesday night.Ardview House, one of the districtrsquos key elderly peoplersquos resource centres, is celebrating its th birthday and a major festival has been organised to mark the occasion.In the early s, Ardview was under threat of closure and only a spirited fightback spearheaded by a former resident, Mrs Kathleen Henry, residents in the village, The Friends of Ardview and local politicians saved the day.The home was spared the axe and since then has featured heavily in a major investment drive by the Down Lisburn Trust which is responsible for managing the facility..prettyPhoto

title: Jetskiers ‘spoiling lough tranquility’
story: A PORTAFERRY woman has claimed that the peace and quiet of Strangford Lough is being spoiled by jet skis.Joan Porter wants the use of jet skis in the area to be more closely monitored, particularly at weekends.Her call comes in the same week as Coastguards in Newcastle received reports of jet skiers putting swimmers at risk.Ms Porter claimed the jet skiers were threatening the fragility of Strangford Loughrsquos wildle.ldquoI live in a very idyllic spot in Portaferry, she said. ldquoThe peace of it, with small boats scudding across the warted and herons idling on the shoreline, makes it one of Northern Irelandrsquos biggest attractions.ldquoBut for weeks now, mostly at weekends and particularly on Sundays, the air and waters of the lough have been under assault by jet skis whinging over the water for hours.Over the weekend of August - there were  skis launching around Cookrsquos Quay at Portaferry and skiing across the lough all day.She went on: ldquoOne of the essential criteria for an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty is stated as lsquorelative tranquility, where natural sounds such as streams of bird-song are predominantrsquo. There is nothing natural about the sound of jet skis.ldquoThe lough has seven statutory nature reserves along its . It is the largest marine natural reserve in the UK. A pair of otters, seals and seal pups are resident where jet skiing is taking place.ldquoAs a journalist I am currently approaching the travel media in England to encourage visitors to come to Northern Ireland for a holiday or short break during the pandemic.ldquoA deion of Strangford Lough on the Visit Ards and North Down website says: lsquoTranquil shores await, offering visitors  days a year destinationrsquo. Tranquil shores  Not any more.Portaferry SDLP councillor Joe Boyle said that while he had sympathy, a balance had to be struck as the economy of the area depended on tourism.ldquoWhile we donrsquot want it to spoil the peace and tranquility, we also donrsquot want to put people off coming to the area, he remarked.ldquoItrsquos dficult as the council doesnrsquot control Strangford Lough, but I have spoken to the council directors about concerns.ldquoThere is a fine line which we donrsquot want to cross andthere are more than  jet skiers, as reported, then it does seem a lot, but this is an area where tourists and watersports enthusiasts want to come to.A sppokesman for Ards and North Down Council said: ldquoCouncil recognises jet skiing is a legitimate and popular sport that many people participate in very responsibly, but equally recognise that in areas like Strangford Lough it must be carefully managed so as not to adversely impact the very special and unique environment and the wider tourism product.Meanwhile, Newcastle Coastguard sent a team to the townrsquos harbour last Wednesday evening after reports that two jet skiers were putting local swimmers at risk.ldquoA large number of people were taking advantage of the fine weather to go swimming and felt the actions of the jet skiers were dangerous and inappropriate, a Coastguard spokesman said.ldquoThe Coastguard team members spoke to the jet skiers, gave safety advice and stayed on scene for some time to monitor the situation.The spokesman added: ldquoAs more and more people take to open sea swimming the Coastguard would urge everyone who takes to the sea in a jet ski, motorised craft or even a canoe to be mindful of the dangers they can cause to swimmers and act accordingly.ldquoWe would also ask that people going to sea be aware of council by-laws that may prohibit them from pursuing their activity at certain locations..prettyPhoto

title: Local children dance up a storm at camp
story: NOW in its fourth year, local Irish dance school Scoil Rince an Chroiacute recently held its summer dance camp which boasted a vibrant programme for all levels of dancers.Each day, the Irish dance school opened the doors of wtheir bespoke dance studio situated off the Downpatrick Road, outside Crossgar, to their Tapping Tots class.Tapping Tots is a unique, custom-made Irish dance programme for pre-school children and is the first of its kind in Northern Ireland.Dance teacher Briacuted McKinney explained: ldquoMovement and rhythm comes naturally to children. Not only does dance allow kids to get their energy out, itrsquos also a great way for children to express themselves. Itrsquos never too early to encourage a love of physical activity in children.Briacuted is passionate about the benefits of dance for young children. ldquoDance is wonderful for coordination. It develops strength and endurance. Through dancing, a toddler will learn from the early age about what their bodies are capable of, she says.ldquo At the same time, it will build their curiosity as naturally they will experiment with certain movements. If toddlers have been introduced to dancing since early age, the chance of them developing good kinesthetic memory is increased.ldquoDuring class we work on key skills such as counting and sequencing thus subtlety engaging with numeracy and literacy. We incorporate sensory props such as ribbons, scarfs, feathers, bubbles and each dancer brings their own favourite toy to dance with. We introduce the foundations of Irish dance and enjoy watching a potential le long journey of dance begin.Following the Tapping Tots class, some  dancers attended the studio for an Irish dance camp with a dference. The week was jam-packed with lots of dancing, fitness, teamwork, arts, crafts and fun.Dance teacher Christopher Owens said: ldquoWe are delighted with the success of our summer dance camp. has posed signicant disappointments for our dancers on a competitive front with event after event being cancelled. We were very determined to give our dancers a fun filled week.Christopher said ing to class post lockdown presented many considerations.ldquoWe faced the challenge of implementing and adhering to government social distancing guidelines.ldquoThankfully our neighbours, East Down Boxing Club, offered us their venue for the week which meant we could cater for so many dancers in a safe manner.ldquoSpecial thanks to support from our dance friends Linda, Edel, Eileen and Sinead who among many things helped assist with enforcing hand hygiene and distance measures.He added: ldquoWersquove thoroughly enjoyed seeing dancers from our locations in Saul, Dromara, Loughinisland, Ballyhornan and Carryduff come together and to see each other again since lockdown began.Deborah Neeson, who is a parent, paid tribute to everyone who helped organise the event, while another parent, Melanie Magee, said her daughter, Caoimhe, had an ldquoamazing and magical time at the summer scheme.ldquoThe teachers where absolutely fantastic and made each day fun-filled with dance and laughs, she said.Personal trainer Roisin Torney was a part of the dance camp schedule. She said: ldquoProgrammes such as this are of enormous benefit to young people. The timing of this dance camp was wonderful to bridge the socialisation gap between lockdown and ing to school over the next two weeks.ldquoYoung people certainly are carrying worry about being back in a group setting and this week has taken down boundaries.Roisin held weekly fitness sessions with the children via Zoom. ldquoItrsquos a pleasure to work with the girls andboys from Scoil Rince an Chroi, she said.ldquoEveryone is so friendly and eager to improve their fitness levels. I love coming out to train with them and look forward to when the dancers canto showcasing their talent and fitness on stage.The physical, mental, and emotional health benefits of dancing are endless. The teaching staff at Scoil Rince an Chroi are dedicated to bringing out the best in all of their dancers no matter age or ability.To find out more about Scoil Rince an Chroi classes which offer Tots classes, beginner classes, competitive classes, classes for adults across County Down and which are due to commence on August , contact Chris on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Mooney magic sinks RGU
story: ROSTREVORrsquoS early goal burst proved too much for Downpatrick to survive on a sun-kissed Friday night in Castlewellan.The match was played in wonderful conditions against the stunning back of the Mournes, but it was the RGU who quickly found themselves with a mountain to climb, conceding a goal after a minute.After some neat, incisive approach play, which was to be the hallmark of Rostrevorrsquos play, particularly in the first half, Conor Doyle punched the ball to the net.They continued to re-enforce that early superiority, with minor scores being added on by Doyle and Piaras Kane.Downpatrick suddenly awoke from their early-game slumber, desperate not to be steamrolled on the big occasion.Conor McGrady was leading the charge back with their first impression on the scoreboard.Downpatrick tagged on a couple more minors, before the contest took another pivotal turn, with Rostrevor again finding a way past RGU goalkeeper James Deeny. This time Ardal McMahon provided the finish as they reached the water break.The RGU management team were left with plenty to ponder. Downpatrick continued to battle after the resumption, determined not to be hit by the threat of an avalanche of Rostrevor scores.At this stage there looked to be a real danger that Rostrevor would cut loose. To their credit, Downpatrick did not throw in the towel.Caolan Mooney burst through on the Downpatrick goal not long before half-time and a penalty was awardedwhen he was up-ended by goalkeeper Deeny. Shaun Parr stepped up and netted Rostrevorrsquos third goal.Downpatrick were given a glimmer of hope just before the interval when Parr and then Sean Cooper were black-carded.However at half-time, and the score at - to -, Downpatrickrsquos task looked onerous.The RGU came out with the right attitude to mount a revival in the second half and Doylersquos early minor reduced the gap.Chris Magee helped lead the Downpatrick forward linersquos continuing assaults on the Rostrevor goal with a couple of scores. And there emerged a real feeling of optimism amongst the massed Downpatrick ranks when Conor McGradyrsquos point left just two in it.However Rostrevor refused to hit the panic button. Guided by the experience of Mooney, they stretched their lead before the next water break.Downpatrick were awarded a penalty with the scoreboard reading - to -. However when Rostrevor needed a big moment at just the right time, goalkeeper Gareth Clarke provided it, plunging to push Tim Prenterrsquos effort to safety.That was the moment which really deflated Downpatrickrsquos resolve. You sensed that Rostrevor knew they had weathered the best that Downpatrick could summon in response to their deficit.Jordan Fegan then broke away in the closing minutes, before splitting the posts and taking Rostrevorrsquos score to -.Kane applied a classy coup de grace with the final score of the evening for the victors when he spun the Downpatrick defence and, bearing down on goal, took the safe option of landing the point.In the end it looked plain sailing on paper for Rostrevor. Certainly in terms of the opening they made to the match, catching the RGU cold, they laid the foundations early that kept many of the worries away that Downpatrick could spring a result on them.To Downpatrickrsquos credit, after that disappointing early start, there were more than enough signs there that the spirit within the camp to dig in and get themselves out of trouble in games is there.Downpatrick: James Deeny, Paddy Smith, Ronan Murphy, Eoin Rooney, Nathan McShane, Gerdie Collins, Conor Doherty, Damian Turley, Jonny Bell, Tim Prenter , Conor McGrady , Conor McCarron , Ruairi Quinn , Peter Turley , Chris Magee .Subs: Jarlath Brannigan , Morgan Fitzpatrick, Caolan Boyd, Damian Branf, Daniel McCarron, Garrett Trainor, Ruairi Og Quinn, Frank Starkey, Tom Savage, Tim Collins, Aidan McNeill, Con Farrell, Aidan Og Robinson.Rostrevor: Gareth Clarke, Jarlath Farrell, Tomas Gordon, Eoin Murdock, Nicky Murray, Colm Murney, James Donaghy, Sean Cooper, Caolan Mooney , Ardghal McMahon , Jordan Fegan , Patrick Magee, Conor Doyle , Shaun Parr, Piaras Kane .Subs: Paul McGrath, Richie Reynolds, Darren McElhinney, Conall Gordon, Eamon McConville. Cormac McGrath, Matthew Grimley, James Rice, Tomas Mulholland, Conor Owen, Eoghan Devlin, Anthony Donnan, Connor Magee..prettyPhoto

title: Mount Crescent ‘could be new community garden’
story: AN area of waste ground at Mount Crescent in Downpatrick has the potential to be transformed into a new community garden for residents, according to a local politician.Cllr John Trainor says the new community facility could be provided as part of the revitalisation and rejuvenation of Downpatrick as the town emerges from le under Covid- restrictions.He says more important than ever for people to be able to get back outside and to have a place where they can come together and enjoy each otherrsquos company.Cllr Trainor said community gardens offered a unique opportunity to provide a place that is safe and secure.ldquoAt Mount Crescent there is something of a secret garden waiting to be opened up and made available to the community, he continued.ldquoThe area of land is ideally located due to its proximity to car parking facilities, Downpatrick Primary School and Down High School. I want people of all ages to be able to enjoy this area and be a part of the lsquore-greeningrsquo of Downpatrick.Cllr Trainor says he understands that the area of land is owned by the Habinteg Housing Association and believes that it could work with local people to transform it.He said the County Down Rural Community Network has been working with Mount Crescent residents on the community garden project for some time.He added: ldquoI believe that the community, working with elected representatives, can ensure that a great community project like this can come to fruition and be of benefit for years to come..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle League in line for October kick off
story: LOCAL soccer is set toin October at the earliest.Newcastle League bosses are targeting a date of October  for ato action mdash almost two months behind normal.However, there is still no clear indication when the Amateur League is set to resume.The league is facing a potential legal challenge over its decision to bring last season to an end prematurely because of the coronavirus pandemic.It is understood that Donaghadee FC, Rosario and Greenisland registered complaints with the Irish FA over the issue.While the IFA says it has no jurisdiction over the matter, the Amateur League still wants a resolution before a start date for the new season is announced.As for the Newcastle League, things are also up in the air, according to league secretary Alan Craig.ldquoAt the moment the earliest we could envisage resuming would be on October , but that of course will be subject to guidelines being in place, that changing facilities are suitable, and pitches are available, he said.ldquoWe also have to consider the wider implications of anyto action for the safety of players, officials and indeed the wider community.ldquoWe are still some way off being able to give definitive answers as to when those issues can be satisfactorily resolved.Last seasonrsquos Bobby Dalzell Cup final between Killough and Ballynahinch Olympic Town and the Harry Clarke Cup decider between Celtic Bhoys and Ballynagross will be played at the start of the new season.The Amateur League has already announced that clubs will not be asked to pay their annual subion fees next season.As to when they may make a , that is a much less clear-cut affair.ldquoIt is a very frustrating situation, league chairman Terry Pateman said.ldquoDonaghadee are seeking arbitration with the Irish FA, and so in that sense we cannot make any plans for a new season.ldquoWe do want to put a date on when we could feasibly start things, but that is not possible at the moment.Mr Pateman also added that when the new season can resume, clubs will have a big role to play in how to adhere to Covid- regulations.ldquoThe advice and rules are out there from the Irish FA and the government, and we want to see clubs abiding by them..prettyPhoto

title: Perfect Posnetts lead way
story: ST Patrickrsquos Golf Club hosted a hugely successful Open Week last week.Glorious weather and a course in ideal condition resulted in big entries and a sizeable contingent of visiting golfers.The action got underway last Tuesday with a mixed scramble and the popular winners were Phil and Yvonne Posnett.The Killyleagh couple romped home with a score of . Second place went to JP and Sheena Burke on ., with Ciaran and Aine McCann third on ..The clubrsquos juvenile golfers were also in action on Tuesday.In the green section the honours went to C Keenan, who finished on  points. Narrowly behind in second was Crossgarrsquos S Carson on  points, with P Kelly also just missing out by one point.In the red section, C OrsquoHare took a commanding first place on  points. E. Murphy was next in on , with P Lindsay third on .In the blue section nine-hole event, C Fitzsimons came home first with a net score of , followed by L Fennell on  and C OrsquoDonnell on .There was a four-way tie at the top of the leaderboard in Wednesdayrsquos singles competition.All four ed  points, but the winner on a count back was Denis McBrin. In second spot was Gerard Taggart, with Darren Killen third and Phil Posnett was fourth.Steven Curran was fth on  points, Barry Fitzsimmons won the gross with a  and the senior section prize went to Hilary McLaughlin with  points.The father-and-son pairing Pauls and Conail Fitzsimons won Fridayrsquos four-ball competition with  points. Noel Rooney and Ciaran Quinn were a point adrt in second place, edging out Gerard and Gregory Teggart on a count back. Sean McMahon and Mark Fitzsimons won the gross with a .Saturdayrsquos singles event was won by Paul Magee with  points, J P Burke was second with  points and Conail Fitzsimons was third with  points. Charlie Mount and Chris Murphy were fourth and fth respectively, also with  points. Barry Fitzsimons picked up another gross prize with a  and Hilary McLaughlin was once again the best of the seniors with  points..prettyPhoto

title: Praise for volunteers at litter pick
story: RESIDENTS in the Spa area who took part in a weekend litter pick have been praised for their efforts.Slieve Croob councillor Alan Lewis said he was delighted with the turn-out and commended the residents on their ldquogreat sense of civic pride.He continued: ldquoI would like to thank everyone who turned up, especially Hannah English who sent out texts, made phone calls and ensured everyone was aware of the event. The Spa is looking well, arguably the tidiest village in Slieve Croob.ldquoI love community events. ldquoItrsquos wonderful to see the local community taking ownership. Well done to all involved..prettyPhoto

title: Super Ciara
story: PORTAFERRYrsquoS Ciara Mageean set a new Irish record when she finished a superb third in the m at the Diamond League meeting in Monaco on Friday night.Mageeanrsquos time of :. took a massive . seconds off the record set by Sonia OrsquoSullivan in  mark and moved her to ninth on the world all-time list.It was  year-old Mageeanrsquos second Irish record in three weeks after she broke the two-minute barrier for m in Bern.Kenyarsquos Olympic m champion Faith Kipyegon clinched her expected victory with a :. clocking which moved her to second on the all-time list behind Svetlanarsquos Masterkovarsquos world mark of :. set in .Scotlandrsquos Laura Muir set a new British record in second place as she crossed the line in :. ndash . seconds ahead of the fast-finishingMageean.Mageean appeared to be slightly impeded with a lap to go as she had check her stride briefly before moving to the outside.However, she moved closer to the leaders during the final m to further emphasise her increased status within the global womenrsquos middle distance fraternity.Given the quality of Friday nightrsquos field, Mageeanrsquos run has to be regarded as the most accomplished of a career which has already seen her win two European medals, a world junior silver and reach last yearrsquos World Championship final in the loaded m.Those behind her included fth-placed world m champion, Halimah Nayaayi of Uganda and US athlete Raevyn Rogers, who won silver in last yearrsquos two-lap event in Doha.Mageeanrsquos time moved her ahead of such luminaries in the world list as  Olympic m champion Maricica Puica , another Romanian great Doina Melinteand Britainrsquos  double Olympic champion Kelly Holmes .Quarantine regulations mean Mageean wonrsquot run in the Irish Championships at Santry over the next two weekends.Monaco and France are not on the green list of countries which allow incoming travellers to Ireland to avoid two weeks in self-isolation on arrival..prettyPhoto

title: Swimming pool reopens at Down Leisure Centre
story: THE swimming pool at Down Leisure Centre has reopened.The Downpatrick pool, as well as those in Kilkeel and Newry, opened its doors again on Monday following the relaxation Covid- restrictions.To begin with, swimmers will be restricted to using swim lanes. Anyone wishing to come along for casual swims and family fun swims can book a slot from this Saturday.To comply with Covid guidelines, Newry, Mourne and Down Council have reduced capacity in the pools and sessions will be strictly  minutes.Users must now also book their own swim slot in advance, via the councilrsquos Be Active App.At present, health suites remain closed and the council wonrsquot be running any swimming lessons just yet as it aims to take a phased approach to reopening of its leisure facilities. This is to ensure the safety of both staff and customers.Although the Council say they are pleased to open its swimming pools again, it wants to make users aware that their experience of using its leisure facilities will not be quite the same as prio to the Covid- pandemic.For user safety, an enhanced cleaning regime will be in place. There will also be clear, visible guidelines about cleanliness and reminders of personal responsibility throughout the facilities.Council chairwoman Laura Devlin said: ldquoWe have been working hard to ensure that we open our leisure facilities in the safest way possible, taking a step-by-step approach to ensure your safety.ldquoWe aim to accommodate as many people as possible, but we need to ensure that we also adhere to government guidelines.ldquoAs well as the key safety measures, such as social distancing and hygiene, there are now practical things people need to consider before they swim, such as coming to pools beach ready, showering at home and paying special attention to pool signage.She added: ldquoI would urge all our keen swimmers in the district to make themselves familiar with our guidance on our website before booking their swim slot and coming along to our swimming pools..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. story: Bereaved RUC families do not carry placards, but we mustn’t forget themThe unionist community is getting older, shrinking, and needs to get serious about the futureNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionBen Lowry: Autumn in Northern Ireland always seems to arrive in late AugustThis year we had one of the best Aprils on record. It was followed by the best May on record .By Ben LowrySaturday, nd August , : pmUpdated Saturday, nd August , : pm""It has been wet across Britain and Ireland over the last week, such as at the shoreline in Saltcoats on the west coast of North Ayrshire above. But in Northern Ireland wet and grey conditions were not that unusual because autumnal weather typically begins in late AugustThe exceptional spring weather helped many people to survive psychologically being trapped at home .I knew we would pay for such a fine April and May. It was a near mathematical certainty that we would get bad summer weather.Average hours of annual sunshine in Northern Ireland are roughly the same from year to year . That means thatthere is a prolonged sunny spell, then – almost necessarily – there will be many dull days, to bring the annual total back towards the statistical norm. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...People enjoy the sunshine on Castlerock beach at the end of May. The weather in Northern Ireland was oustanding in April and May, which meant some form of payback was due in terms of lots of dull summer days, writes Ben Lowry. Picture: Michael CooperAnd sure enough we suffered payback. July was the dullest in NI in more than  years, according to Armagh Observatory. It was also wetter and cooler than average.August has been poor, particularly the last week. I associate late August with the onset of autumn.While the Mediterranean gets hot weather into October and southern England is warm until late September, Northern Ireland summers end early.My late uncle rented a house on the north coast in the last week of each August. I have happy memories of those trips but not of the weather. It has been wet across Britain and Ireland over the last week, such as at the Front Strand in Youghal, Co. Cork above on Wednesday. But in Northern Ireland it was not that unusual because autumnal weather typically begins in late August. title: ben lowry return general lockdown not even remotely feasible
story: Bereaved RUC families do not carry placards, but we mustn’t forget themThe unionist community is getting older, shrinking, and needs to get serious about the futureNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionBen Lowry: Ato general lockdown is not even remotely feasibleThe prospect of ato full lockdown has been floated.By Ben LowrySaturday, nd August , : pmUpdated Saturday, nd August , : pm""Crowds enjoyed the hot weather at Bournemouth beach at the end of May, as lockdown restrictions began to be eased after two months. There were growing reports of teenage parties after this time, because there is only so long that people will accept massive restrictionsThe chief medical officer for Northern Ireland, Dr Michael Maguire, said he would recommend such sweeping restrictionsCovid- infections hit  people per , .Robin Swann, the health minister, also gave warning that ato lockdown could not be ruled out,cases keep rising.Dr McBride, as a health official who lacks an elected mandate, was careful to say that it was not ultimately his call. He said that any recommendations would “need to go to the executive at the appropriate time for them to make a decision”. " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...That is the traditional protocol. Now, however, western world politicians often defer big decisions to committees or experts, rather than make hard choices themselves.Even the supposedly radical Tory government in London, whichwants to shake up how the UK is governed, has hidden its pandemic decision making behind scientists.The A Level-GCSE fiasco is rooted in the cowardice that led to UK schools being shut earlier than the government wanted, and staying closed for longer.Even now teaching unions and other voices are trying to stop a fullto school next month, when in fact there should have been a push to get pupils back in the weeks after Easter– or at least exam years.There are four broad reasons why ato anything like the general lockdown we experienced after March  is not plausible.• The first is that the nation can’t afford to sustain the furlough schemeIt has already pushed debt to perilous levels. If furlough was extended into next year, there would need to be massive tax increases and spending cuts, including public sector pay cuts .NI politicians have no stomach for such toughness. Even in a financial crisis, Stormont seems only ever inclined to grant pay rises, including a huge recent teacher rise. Councils abused furlough by topping up Treasury funding of % of salaries with ratepayer cash to ensure no staff had any pay reduction.• The second reason lockdown is not feasible is the public mood. The UK government has been fairly criticised for the many things it did wrong over Covid, but few people cite thingsit got right. Its behavioural experts saidlockdown came in too early people would get fed up after a while, and begin to break it. That began to happen after two months. In June there were growing reports of young people socialising in groups .As well as fatigue with restrictions, people began to develop an instinctive sense of the risk of Covid, similar to how we assess car travel .• The third reason lockdown is not feasible is that infection levels do not justy such a massive response.Even the level cited by Dr McBride –  per , cases – is low according to some experts. Prof Carl Heneghan of Oxford’s Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine said epidemic level is five times higher .He said people were failing to understand, and balance, risks.Mr Swann and Dr McBride have accepted such balance over schooling .But such balancing equations should be applied more widely .Few politicians are candid that the Covid risk cannot be cut to zero.Sweden’s former state epidemiologist Prof Johan Giesecke said from the outset that it was not possible to halt Covid’s spread. Recent upsurges in case even in nations that were seen as models of control, such as Germany and South Korea, have vindicated that prediction. • The fourth reason another lockdown is not feasible is specic to NI: Bobby Storey’s funeral shattered Stormont’s authority. There was a cross-party determination to protect Sinn Fein . This meant the first and deputy first ministers cannot preside over press briefings that might reveal suspension of liberty.Instead, the political parties erted attention from the calculating nature of SF leaders’ social distancing breach on June  in westBelfast by backing probes into important but secondary matters such as PSNI and Belfast council handling of the funeral. But in the absence of sanction against hypocritical leaders who set the rules, the damage is irreparable. A population that for months largely obeyed lockdown, including missing funerals of loved ones, watched as republicans were allowed to do as they pleased.• Ben Lowryis News Letter deputy editor• Ben Lowry: Autumn in Northern Ireland always seems to arrive in late August——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: lough neaghs annual pest really thriving
story: Bereaved RUC families do not carry placards, but we mustn’t forget themThe unionist community is getting older, shrinking, and needs to get serious about the futureNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsOpinionLough Neagh’s annual pest is really thrivingComing from the South Derry area I always imagined when I was young thatI married I would definitely want to live there.By The NewsroomSaturday, nd August , : am""Columnist: Sandra ChapmanFrom our garden we had a splendid view of Slieve Gallion mountain, there was the River Bann where we went fishing, and best of all there was Lough Neagh where with my siblings and endless cousins we fiddled around in boats and camped on the sandy bits which hadn’t disappear over the previous winter. I was a mere child then and childhood dreams develop realism as time moves on.The family home eventually became too small for us and we moved on, but not far away. My mother pined to get back to the area which she eventually did by which time I had left school, had started working and soon that meant living away from home except for the Christmas holidays. That was the one time of the year you could be guaranteed to escape what we called the midges or mayflies, to give them their proper title, harmless little blighters but a great nuisance. And this year, particularly this month, it seems, those mayflies are ‘torturing‘ the locals because August is the month of the mayfly andit’s a good, warm month they breed in their zillions.I remember having to close up bedroom windows at night andI went to visit my elderly Aunt Lizzie, who lived right on the shore at Ballyronan, she kept a permanently rolled up newspaper which she took everywhere with her.  " fill"#ea" to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Her laneway was fairly long and when I visited I always dreaded having to cycle though this buzzing throng with mouth closed and breath held until I could reach her front door.The mayflies first arrive in May but this balmy warm August, has been particularly perfect weather for the second generation of little blighters on all shores of the lough. Barbeques  Out of the question. Strolling around the shore on a calm evening  Forget it. The mayflies cover the walls of houses and the windows, for all the world resembling a black plague. My mother would spend her mornings shovelling them away from the doors and windows yes, even those that got inside. When the well-known McGarry Brothers were building boats on the shore not far from BallyronanI recall seeing the dead flies stacked high in their boatyard, the perfect dung heap for locals keen for valuable free compost for their gardens.Tennis, GAA matches, even paddling on the shore was out of the question when the flies took over.The sadness of it all is that most parts of the shores of Lough Neagh are scenically beautul and understandably people want to build homes there. Those who haven’t done their homework and have built a home overlooking the water will get a shock when the first tranche of mayflies arrive.These creatures spread themselves over everything including the highest trees. Fly killing sprays are useless. They come, set up home and don’t die off or go away until it suits them. And, it was that that persuaded me that no matter how much I loved the place I could never live there. I wasn’t even keen to visit the family home until the flies had gone.I try to avoid driving in the area when the mayflies are active as they splatter the windscreen ruining your vision and needing to be scraped off because they harden like glue. Step ouside the car and you’re covered in them.In sense they are not unlike the coronavirus – a first tranche arrives taking lives and scaring us witless. We try to get it under control only for a second lot to move in or at least we have been told to expect one. Even our scientists are fairly certain the virus willwith the cold weather. Our Health Minister Robin Swann has us well warned. So the police needed go looking for beach parties or illegal raves around the shores of Lough Neagh. These results should be in today or tomorrow at the latest but sadly we cannot open until we are certain that everyone employed at Thompsons is in the clear.In the interim the entire venue is undergoing a deep clean, fumigation and decontamination in preparation for re-opening this weekend.. Our team will be in contact with everyone who has made bookings for tonight and this weekend.We’ll keep you posted on any developments! #staysafe”.Earlier today it emerged that a popular Co Londonderry bar - Dormans in Magherafelt - was closing temporarily after a number of customers tested positive for COVID-.In a statement on their Facebook page Dormans Bar said: “Since reopening our premises after lockdown we introduced in line with government guidelines stringent safety measures to ensure the protection of both our staff and customers. “We are totally committed to these measures which are constantly under review and improvement.“We however, despite the stringent safety measures we have in place, regret to inform you that three customers who visited our premises over the weekend of - August, have tested positive for Covid . “This information was supplied to us through NI Public Health Department’s Track and Trace System.“According to government guidelines we can reopen after a deep clean as it’s an isolated case but to ensure the protection of the health, welfare and safety of our staff and customers we have decided to close the premises this weekend and until all our staff have been tested, their results checked and the premises have undergone a thorough professional deep clean.“We are absolutely devastated that this has happened but unfortunately it is a situation that is unavoidable and which a lot of businesses will face in the coming months.“Thank you to all our customers for your support and our sincerest apologies for any inconveniences caused by our temporary closure.“Dormans Bar “Meanwhile, it has also emerged that two members of staff at the Galgorm Spa and Golf Resort near Ballymena have tested positive for COVID-.In a statement they said: “Galgorm Spa  Golf Resort confirmed today that it has increased safety measures for guests and team members amid concerns over an increase of Covid- cases in a number of areas across Northern Ireland, including Mid  East Antrim.It has also confirmed that following its own robust testing procedures, two asymptomatic team members who tested positive for Covid- on Thursday have been self-isolating at home, in line with company policy. The employees affected were back-of-house and had no contact with guests. The Resort’s senior team remains in regular communication with those impacted to provide support and a further test will be carried out with both team members prior to ato work.Galgorm Collection Managing Director, Colin Johnston, said:“We share the concerns around the recent increase in the number of Covid- cases and, like many employers in the area, we have been monitoring this extremely closely. In response, we have already put additional measures in place.Last week, we moved to the next phase of our agreed, comprehensive Hygiene Commitment plan which includes increased random testing of team members, who continue to operate within team bubbles.In addition, we are also the first company in Northern Ireland to introduce a Mistpal Cleansing Tunnel for team members and guests entering the Resort for further safety reassurance. This is in addition to already established measures including a nightly, full deep-clean of all areas with hospital-grade sanitiser protectant and decontamination equipment, thermal temperature monitoring, provision of hand sanitisers in all areas and adherence to recommended social distancing guidelines.The health and safety of our team and guests remains paramount and we are grateful for their continued support and also to those guests who have rescheduled their stay as a result of the robust pre-entry testing measures we have in place.”Galgorm Spa  Golf Resort has already carried out tests with almost  team members and will continue to conduct random testing and adopt the same stringent protocols already in place in the event that any further positive cases are identied.Since reopening Galgorm Spa  Golf Resort has been focused on safety as a priority and was among the first hotels in the UK to receive the AA COVID Confident Mark for its industry leading health and safety standards. It continues to work with local, regional and UK government bodies to uphold its stringent hygiene standards”. A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. today agreed changes to the Coronavirus Health Regulations to reduce the numbers who can gather indoors and outdoors, including in domestic settings.Currently up to  people from four households can meet indoors and  in a garden.The amendments will reduce the number that can meet indoors to six people from two households.The number of people that can participate in an outdoor gathering, including in a private garden, will also change from the current  people to .Certain events can have more than  people attending as long as a risk assessment is carried out and necessary measures are put in place.This will include weddings, church services and sporting events where a close adherence to social distancing and hygiene regimes continues to apply.The Executive also agreed some upper limits on gatherings and events that can be introduced quickly depending on the transmission of the disease.The changes will be introduced next week.The changes will apply across Northern Ireland, but the Executive accepted that localised measures may be needed in the future to arrest the spread of the virus.With the transmission of the virus increasing in the community and the R number currently at story: Bereaved RUC families do not carry placards, but we mustn’t forget themThe unionist community is getting older, shrinking, and needs to get serious about the futureNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensCoronavirusFarmingNewsWeatherSoggy and stormy spell leaves NI doused – and sets new local windspeed recordsThe recent stormy spell saw some weather stations in the Province inundated with over a quarter of a month’s rainfall in a single  hour period – and it also set new records for blustery weather.By Adam KulaSaturday, nd August , : amUpdated Saturday, nd August , : am""A cyclist is hit by a wave as he cycles along the shoreline in Saltcoats on the west coast of North Ayrshire as gusts of up to mph could hit coastal areas as Storm Ellen moves on and leaves more wet and windy weather in its wake.The wintry Storm Ellen which battered the nation through Thursday and into yesterday saw seven out of the Province’s  weather stations record their highest wind speeds ever for the month of August, according to data from the Met Office.l The highest such reading was at Thomastown, a townland to the south-east of Enniskillen. There, wind speed overnight from Thursday into yesterday hit mph – a new record for that station in the month of August.The previous highest August windspeed there had been mph in . rain, the Met Office said the wettest place in the Province was Ballypatrick Forest in north Antrim.There, . mm of rain fell between am on Friday and am on Saturday.To put that in context, the average rainfall across NI for the whole month of August is . mm.l The second-highest rainfall reading during the storm was at Stormont in Belfast, where . mm of rain was recorded in the same -hour period.l
